title: Campana rational connectedness and weak approximation

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Campana introduced a notion of Campana rational connectedness for Campana orbifolds. Given a Campana fibration over a complex curve, we prove that a version of weak approximation for Campana sections holds at places of good reduction when the general fiber satisfies a slightly stronger version of Campana rational connectedness. Campana also conjectured that any Fano orbifold is Campana rationally connected; we verify a stronger statement for toric Campana orbifolds. A key tool in our study is log geometry and moduli stacks of stable log maps.

## CONTENTS

1. Introduction 1
2. Deformation theory for log maps 5
3. Deformation theory for log sections 19
4. Free log curves 22
5. Campana maps and curves 26
6. Weak approximation 28
7. Campana curves for $\mathbb{P}^{1}$-fibrations 33
8. Rational Campana curves in toric varieties 35
References 40

## 1. InTRODUCTION

One of the major goals in arithmetic algebraic geometry is to understand rational points on algebraic varieties defined over the function field of a smooth projective curve over an algebraically closed field. By the valuative criterion, this amounts to studying the spaces of sections of fibrations over curves. In characteristic 0 [GHS03, Theorem 1.1] showed that any rationally connected fibration admits a section, and moreover by [HT06, Theorem 3] we know that weak approximation holds for such fibrations at places of good reduction.

On the other hand, in arithmetic geometry a major topic of interest is semi-integral points on Campana orbifolds. Recent activity has focused on the notion of Campana points which interpolate between rational points and integral points. Many conjectures on rational/integral points admit a version for Campana points, e.g., [AVA18, PSTVA21, MNS24]. Some recent works analyzing these conjectures include [BY21, Xia22, Str22, Shu22, PS24, NS24, CLTBT24, Moe24]. However, there is still only limited evidence supporting these conjectures and more investigation is required to formulate them precisely. In this paper,

we study Campana curves/sections and explore the validity of weak approximation in the setting of Campana sections.

We first lay down the foundation of Campana curves/sections using log geometry and moduli stacks of stable log maps. Then we reinterpret the notion of orbifold rational connectedness introduced by Campana and show that this notion is equivalent to a stronger property called Campana rational connectedness. Then we prove that for any fibration whose general fibers satisfy a version of Campana rational connectedness, weak approximation for Campana sections at places of good reduction holds. Finally we verify this property for toric Campana orbifolds.
1.1. Campana curves. Throughout the paper, our ground field is an algebraically closed field $\mathbf{k}$ of arbitrary characteristic $p=\operatorname{char} \mathbf{k}$, but for simplicity we assume that $\mathbf{k}$ has characteristic 0 in this introduction.

Let $\underline{X}$ be a smooth projective variety equipped with a strict normal crossings (SNC) divisor $\Delta=\cup_{i} \Delta_{i}$. Let $X$ be the $\log$ scheme associated to $(\underline{X}, \Delta)$. (See Section 2.1 for its definition.) To each irreducible component $\Delta_{i}$ we assign a weight

$$
\epsilon_{i}=1-\frac{1}{m_{i}}
$$

where $m_{i} \geq 1$ is an integer. We then define the effective $\mathbb{Q}$-divisor

$$
\Delta_{\epsilon}=\sum_{i} \epsilon_{i} \Delta_{i}
$$

The pair $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is called a klt Campana orbifold (in the sense of [Cam04, Section 1.2.1]). Note that for a Campana orbifold we always assume the pair $(X, \Delta)$ is log smooth; we include the term klt to emphasize that the coefficients of $\Delta_{\epsilon}$ are smaller than 1.

Definition 1.1. Let $(\pi: C \rightarrow S, f: C \rightarrow X)$ be a stable log map with the canonical log structure such that $S$ is a geometric log point with the trivial log structure. (This implies that the underlying scheme $\underline{C}$ is irreducible and smooth and the image $f(C)$ is not contained in the boundary $\Delta$.) Let $p_{k}$ be a marked point and $\mathbf{c}_{k}=\left(c_{k, i}\right)$ be the contact order, i.e., $c_{k, i}$ is the local multiplicity of $f^{*} \Delta_{i}$ at $p_{k}$. We say $f: C \rightarrow X$ is a Campana curve for $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ if $c_{k, i} \geq m_{i}$ whenever $c_{k, i} \neq 0$.

Log geometry controls deformations of stable log maps. Since log deformations keep the contact orders constant, log geometry is particularly useful to understand deformations of Campana curves. In this paper, we lay down the foundation of Campana curves using log geometry.

A central theme in our work is the existence of Campana rational curves on Campana orbifolds. The following definition is a variant of the notions of orbifold uniruledness and orbifold rational connectedness pioneered by Campana, e.g., [Cam11a, Cam10, Cam11b]:

Definition 1.2. Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Campana orbifold. We say $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is Campana uniruled if there is a dominant family of genus 0 Campana curves whose underlying curves have nontrivial numerical class. Moreover, if any two general points on $X$ are contained in a family of Campana curves of genus 0 that dominates $X$, we say $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is Campana rationally connected.

As in the case of rational curves, we prove that these two notions are respectively equivalent to the existence of free or very free Campana rational curves in characteristic 0.

Remark 1.3. The "orbifold" notions due to Campana are presented differently but turn out to be equivalent to Definition 1.2. We discuss the relationship in Remark 7.3.

In [Cam11a, Section 5.4], Campana made several precise conjectures about the relationship between Campana uniruledness and the behavior of the orbifold tangent bundle. We will primarily be interested in the following conjecture, which is a special case of [Cam11b, Conjecture 9.10] and provides the main source of examples of Campana rational connectedness.

Conjecture 1.4. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ has characteristic 0 . Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Fano orbifold, i.e, $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is a klt Campana orbifold and $-\left(K_{\underline{X}}+\Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is ample. Then $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is Campana rationally connected.

Example 1.5 (Campana). Here we introduce examples of Campana rationally connected orbifolds found by Campana. Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Fano orbifold such that all irreducible components $\Delta_{i}$ have the same multiplicity $m \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 1}$. Assume that the boundary divisor $\Delta=\sum_{i} \Delta_{i}$ is divisible by $m$ in $\operatorname{Pic}(\underline{X})$. Let $\rho: \underline{Y} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ be the degree $m$ cyclic cover of $X$ totally ramified along $\Delta$. Then since we have

$$
-K_{\underline{Y}}=-\rho^{\kappa}\left(K_{\underline{X}}+\Delta_{\epsilon}\right)
$$

the variety $\underline{Y}$ is a klt Fano variety. By [Zha06, Theorem 1] or [HM07, Corollary 1.3 and Corollary 1.5] $\underline{Y}$ is rationally connected. Then note that any rational curve on $\underline{Y}$ is a Campana rational curve on $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ after imposing the canonical log structure, so in particular $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is Campana rationally connected. Such a construction applies when $\underline{X}$ is a smooth Fano complete intersection in $\mathbb{P}^{n}$ and $\Delta$ is a SNC divisor which is the restriction of a Cartier divisor on $\mathbb{P}^{n}$.
1.2. Main results. Let $B$ be a smooth projective curve defined over $\mathbf{k}$ with the trivial log structure. Let $\underline{\mathcal{X}}$ be a smooth projective variety equipped with a flat morphism $\pi: \underline{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow B$ whose fibers are connected. Let $\Delta=\cup_{i} \Delta_{i}$ be a SNC divisor on $\underline{\mathcal{X}}$ such that $\left.\pi\right|_{\Delta}: \bar{\Delta} \rightarrow B$ is flat and let $\mathcal{X}$ be the log scheme associated to $(\underline{\mathcal{X}}, \Delta)$. By a klt Campana fibration $\left(\mathcal{X} / B, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$, we mean the data of a klt Campana orbifold $\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ equipped with a fibration $\pi: \underline{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow B$ as described above. In the setting of a klt Campana fibration, one is interested in the moduli space of $\log$ sections $\sigma: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ which satisfy the Campana condition.

A Campana jet for $\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is a jet whose local multiplicities satisfy the Campana condition. (See Definition 6.2 for a precise definition.) Then a natural question is whether analogues of the existence of a section [GHS03, Theorem 1.1] and weak approximation at places of good reduction [HT06, Theorem 3] hold in the setting of Campana sections. Assuming a slightly stronger version of Campana uniruledness, we answer these questions affirmatively.

Theorem 1.6. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 . Let $\pi$ : $\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ be a klt Campana fibration over $\mathbf{k}$ such that a general fiber of $\pi$ is rationally connected and is strongly Campana uniruled (in the sense of Definition 5.9). Let $S$ be a finite set of closed points on $B$ and assume that $\underline{\pi}: \underline{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow B$ satisfies weak approximation outside of $S$. Fix a finite number of Campana jets supported on distinct fibers which are at places outside of $S$. Then this finite set of Campana jets is induced by a Campana section.

In particular by [HT06, Theorem 3] this theorem applies by letting $S$ to be the set of places of bad reduction of $\underline{\pi}: \underline{X} \rightarrow B$.

As a corollary, we obtain
Corollary 1.7. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 . Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Campana orbifold over $\mathbf{k}$ such that $\underline{X}$ is rationally connected and $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is strongly Campana uniruled. Then $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is Campana rationally connected, i.e., there is a family of Campana curves passing through two general points on $X$.

Finally, we add to the list of examples where Conjecture 1.4 is known by verifying the conjecture for toric varieties.

Theorem 1.8. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 . Let $\underline{X}$ be a smooth projective toric variety over $\mathbf{k}$ and $\Delta$ be the torus-invariant boundary on $\underline{X}$. Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Campana orbifold. Then $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is strongly Campana uniruled as well as Campana rationally connected.
Remark 1.9. In characteristic 0, Campana noticed that for toric Campana orbifolds, Campana uniruledness easily follows by looking at toric rational curves. Here we establish something stronger so that Theorem 1.6 applies. We should also note that this theorem is established in positive characteristic too. See Theorem 8.2 for more details.

As a corollary of this theorem, we deduce a version of Theorem 1.6 when the generic fiber is toric which places no restriction on the fibers containing the jets:
Corollary 1.10. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 . Let $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ be a klt Campana fibration over $\mathbf{k}$ such that the generic fiber $\left(\mathcal{X}_{\eta}, \Delta_{\eta}\right)$ is a smooth projective toric variety with the toric boundary. Fix a finite number of Campana jets supported on distinct fibers of $\underline{\pi}: \underline{X} \rightarrow B$. Then these finite Campana jets are induced by a Campana section.

# 1.3. Related works. 

Weak approximation by sections. Existence/weak approximation of sections for rationally connected fibrations has been extensively studied. As mentioned before, there is a celebrated work [GHS03] showing the existence of sections in characteristic 0 . This is extended to separably rationally connected fibrations in arbitrary characteristic in [dJS03]. Weak approximation at places of good reduction has been established in [HT06] in characteristic 0, and there are many more results in this direction, e.g., [Xu12a, Xu12b, Tia15, TZ18, TZ19, SX20, STZ22].
$\mathbb{A}^{1}$-connectedness. As a notion corresponding to integral points, $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-curves and $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-connectedness have been studied by various authors. This has been first pioneered by Miyanishi and his collaborators, e.g., [Miy78, GM92, GMMR08], and there is an important work by KeelMcKernan [KM99] on the existence of free rational curves on quasi-projective surfaces. More recently $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-curves have been studied by the first author and Yi Zhu using log geometry and deformation theory for stable log maps ([CZ15, CZ19, CZ18]) Surprisingly log Fano varieties with a reduced boundary do not need to satisfy $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-connectedness, e.g., the projective plane with a union of two lines as a boundary. Moreover in characteristic $p>0$, dlt log Fano varieties consisting of a projective space of dimension $n \geq p$ with any smooth degree $p$ boundary are at best separably $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-uniruled, and fail to be $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-separably connected in general [CC21].

Weak approximation by Campana points. There are a few papers studying weak approximation property by Campana points in the arithmetic setting. The paper [NS24] discusses a relation between weak approximation property and the Hilbert property. [MNS24] is the first paper studying Brauer-Manin obstructions in the setting of semi-integral points. Finally [Moe24] addresses the weak approximation property for Campana points and related notions for split toric varieties.

Campana orbifolds and orbifold rational connectedness. Campana introduced the notion of Campana orbifolds in his studies of special manifolds, and he developed the theory of orbifold rational curves and orbifold rational connectedness in [Cam11a, Cam10, Cam11b]. Orbifold rational connectedness is equivalent to Campana rational connectedness as defined in Definition 1.2.
1.4. The plan of the paper. In Section 2, we discuss the deformation theory of log maps and exhibit a few constructions of log gluing and log splitting which are used later. In Section 3, we develop the deformation theory of log sections. In Section 4, we introduce separable uniruledness and separable connectedness by rational log curves and show that these notions are equivalent to the existence of free or very free rational log curves respectively. In Section 5, we introduce the notion of Campana maps and sections, and we also introduce the notion of Campana uniruledness and Campana rational connectedness. In Section 6, we define Campana jets and weak approximation by Campana sections. Then we prove Theorem 1.6. In Section 7, we discuss the case of $\mathbb{P}^{1}$-fibrations and prove Conjecture 1.4 in this case. We also prove that orbifold rational connectedness is equivalent to Campana rational connectedness in Remark 7.3. Finally in Section 8, we discuss the case of toric orbifolds and prove Theorem 1.8 and Corollary 1.10.

Acknowledgements: The authors thank Brendan Hassett, Jason Starr, Yuri Tschinkel, and Chenyang Xu for answering our questions. The authors also thank Boaz Moerman for his comments on the first draft of the paper and Enhao Feng for pointing out some mistakes. # 2. Deformation theory for log maps 

We work over an algebraically closed field $\mathbf{k}$. In this section we have two goals. First, we introduce some terminology for log schemes and stable log maps. Second, we discuss the deformation theory of stable log maps (possibly with added constraints).
2.1. Log maps and their stacks. Let $\underline{X}$ be a smooth variety and $\Delta \subset \underline{X}$ be a strict normal crossings divisor. Denote by $\Delta=\cup_{i} \Delta_{i}$ the decomposition into smooth irreducible components.

Let $X=\left(\underline{X}, \mathcal{M}_{X}\right)$ be the log scheme associated to the pair $(\underline{X}, \Delta)$, where $\mathcal{M}_{X}$ is the sheaf of monoids over $\underline{X}$ defined by

$$
\mathcal{M}_{X}(U):=\left\{f \in \mathcal{O}_{\underline{X}}(U)|f|_{U \backslash \Delta} \in \mathcal{O}_{\underline{X}}^{\times}(U \backslash \Delta)\right\}
$$

for any open subscheme $U \subset \underline{X}$. The $\log$ tangent bundle $T_{X}$ is the subsheaf of $T_{\underline{X}}$ consisting of vector fields tangent to $\Delta$. Its dual $\Omega_{X}=T_{X}^{\vee}$ is the log cotangent bundle consisting of differentials with at most logarithmic poles along $\Delta$.

Notation 2.1. For any log scheme (or log stack) $Y$, we denote by $\mathcal{M}_{Y}$ its log structure and by $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{Y}:=\mathcal{M}_{Y} / \mathcal{O}_{Y}^{*}$ the corresponding characteristic sheaf.

For any log morphism $f: X \rightarrow Y$ between two log schemes or log stacks, the morphism $f^{s}: f^{*} \mathcal{M}_{Y} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{X}$ (resp. $\bar{f}^{s}: f^{*} \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{Y} \rightarrow \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{X}$ ) denotes the corresponding morphism on the level of log structures (resp. characteristic sheaves).

Any scheme $\underline{X}$ can be viewed as a log scheme with the trivial log structure $\mathcal{M}_{\underline{X}}=\mathcal{O}_{\underline{X}}^{*}$. We assume all log structures are fine and saturated, or fs for short, unless otherwise stated. For the basics of logarithmic structures, we refer to the foundational paper of Kato [Kat89] and the comprehensive book [Ogu18].
Definition 2.2. A $\log$ curve over a $\log$ scheme $S$ consists of a pair

$$
\left(\pi: C \rightarrow S,\left\{p_{1}, \cdots, p_{n}\right\}\right)
$$

such that
(1) The underlying pair $\left(\underline{\pi},\left\{p_{1}, \cdots, p_{n}\right\}\right)$ is a family of pre-stable curves over $\underline{S}$ with $n$ markings.
(2) $\pi$ is a proper, log smooth, and integral morphism of log schemes.
(3) If $U \subset \underline{C}$ is the smooth locus of $\underline{\pi}$ then $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid_{U} \cong \underline{\pi}^{*} \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{S} \oplus \bigoplus_{k=1}^{n} p_{k *} \mathbb{N}_{\underline{S}}$.

Here $\mathbb{N}_{\underline{S}}$ denotes the constant sheaf on $\underline{S}$ with coefficients $\mathbb{N}$.
Let $S$ be a log scheme. A log map over $S$ is a morphism of log schemes $f: C \rightarrow X$ such that $C \rightarrow S$ is a family of log curves. In particular, the underlying family $\underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{S}$ obtained by removing all log structures is a family of pre-stable curves. It is called stable if the corresponding underlying morphism $\underline{f}$ is stable in the usual sense. A $\log \operatorname{map} f$ is said to be non-degenerate if $S$ is a log point with the trivial log structure. In this case, $\underline{C}$ is a smooth irreducible curve and $\mathcal{M}_{C}$ is the divisorial log structure coming from the markings. Furthermore in this case we can conclude that $f(C) \not \subset \Delta$.

The theory of log maps of Abramovich-Chen-Gross-Siebert [Che14, AC14, GS13] is one of the main tools in this paper. Let $f: C \rightarrow X$ be a non-degenerate log map and let $p_{k} \in C$ be the $k$-th marked point. Let $c_{k, i}$ be the order of tangency of $f$ with respect to $\Delta_{i}$ at $p_{k}$. The collection of non-negative integers $\mathbf{c}_{k}=\left(c_{k, i}\right)_{i}$ is called the contact order at $p_{k}$. Log geometry allows us to further extend this definition to all log maps, not only the non-degenerate ones.

We recall the definition of contact orders at a node as described by [Che14, §3.2] and [AC14, §4.1]. Let $f: C \rightarrow X$ be a log map over a log point $S$, and $p \in C$ be a node with image $f(p)=x$. Define the relative characteristic sheaf $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C / S}:=\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} / \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{S}$. Recall that $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C / S} \mid_{p} \cong \mathbb{Z}$ where this isomorphism depends on a choice of sign. Consider the composition

$$
u_{p}:\left.\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{X}\right|_{x} \xrightarrow{\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{p}} \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \|_{p} \longrightarrow \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C / S} \|_{p} \cong \mathbb{Z}
$$

Suppose $J=\left\{i \mid x \in \Delta_{i}\right\}$. Then $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{X} \mid x \cong \mathbb{N}^{|J|}$ with the generator $\delta_{i} \in \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{X} \mid x$ corresponding to $\Delta_{i}$. Write $c_{p, i}:=u_{p}\left(\delta_{i}\right)$ if $i \in J$ and $c_{p, i}=0$ otherwise. As a morphism of monoids, $u_{p}$ is uniquely determined by the collection of integers $\left(c_{p, i}\right)_{i}$. The contact order at the node $p$ is the collection $\left(c_{p, i}\right)_{i}$. Note that the contact order at a node depends on the choice of sign in the isomorphism $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C / S} \mid p \cong \mathbb{Z}$. However, this difference will not be important in this paper; we will only care about the divisibility properties of the contact order.

Notation 2.3. Consider a contact order $\mathbf{c}_{k}=\left(c_{k, i}\right)_{i}$ of a marking or a node. We say that a contact order is positive if all the entries are non-negative and at least one entry is not zero. A marking or a node is a contact marking if its contact order is positive; otherwise, it is called a non-contact marking. For an integer $m \in \mathbb{N}$, we wrote $\mathbf{c}_{k} \geq m$ if $c_{k, i} \geq m$ for all $i$. We write char $\mathbf{k} \mid \mathbf{c}_{k}$ if char $\mathbf{k} \mid c_{k, i}$ for all $i$, and write char $\mathbf{k} \nmid \mathbf{c}_{k}$ otherwise.

For later use, denote by $\underline{X}_{\boldsymbol{c}_{k}}:=\cap_{\mathrm{c}_{k, i} \neq 0} \Delta_{i}$ with the trivial log structure if $\mathbf{c}_{k} \neq 0$, and $\underline{X}_{\boldsymbol{c}_{k}}=\underline{X}$ if $\mathbf{c}_{k}=0$. Further denote by $\underline{X}_{\boldsymbol{c}_{k}}^{=} \subset \underline{X}_{\boldsymbol{c}_{k}}$ the maximal open dense locus such that $\underline{X}_{\boldsymbol{c}_{k}}^{=} \cap \underline{\Delta}_{i}=\emptyset$ for any index $i$ such that $c_{k, i}=0$.

The discrete data of a stable log map to $X$ is the triple

$$
\left(g, \varsigma=\left\{\mathbf{c}_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{|\varsigma|}, \beta\right)
$$

where $g$ denotes the genus of the domain curve, $\beta$ is a curve class on $\underline{X},|\varsigma|$ is the number of markings, and $\mathbf{c}_{k}$ is the contact order at the $k$-th marked point.

Let $\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta)$ be the category of stable log maps to $X$ with the discrete data (2.1) fibered over the category of log schemes. It was proved in [Che14, AC14, GS13, Wis16] that $\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta)$ is represented by a log algebraic stack, i.e. it is an algebraic stack equipped with a fine and saturated log structure. Further assuming characteristic zero, then $\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta)$ is a proper, log Deligne-Mumford stack. Let $\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}^{\circ}(X, \beta) \subset \mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta)$ be the open sub-stack with the trivial log structure. Then $\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}^{\circ}(X, \beta)$ is the stack parametrizing non-degenerate stable log maps with the discrete data assigned in (2.1).
2.2. Deformations of $\log$ maps. For any $\log$ stack $\mathfrak{M}$, denote by $\log _{\mathfrak{M}}$ Olsson's $\log$ stack constructed in [Ols03]: to any underlying morphism $\underline{S} \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}$ the stack associates the category of morphisms of $\log$ stacks $S \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}$. The universal $\log$ structure of $\log _{\mathfrak{M}}$ defines the tautological morphism of $\log$ stacks $\log _{\mathfrak{M}} \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}$. Consider

$$
\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }:=\log _{\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}}
$$

where $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}$ is the moduli stack of pre-stable curves equipped with the canonical log structure [Kat00, Ols07]. The stack $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }$ is $\log$ smooth. Hence the locus in $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }$ with the trivial $\log$ structure is open dense and maps isomorphically via the tautological morphism to the open substack of $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}$ parametrizing smooth curves. In particular, $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }$ is reduced and irreducible of dimension

$$
\operatorname{dim} \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }=3 g-3+|\varsigma|
$$

Let $\mathfrak{C}_{g,|\varsigma|} \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}$ be the universal log curve. Consider the pull-back of log stacks

$$
\mathfrak{C}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }:=\mathfrak{C}_{g,|\varsigma|} \times_{\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}} \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log } \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }
$$

It is a universal family in the following sense. Let $C \rightarrow S$ be a $\log$ curve of genus $g$ with $|\varsigma|$ markings. Then there is a natural (not necessarily strict) morphism $S \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}$ such

that $C \rightarrow S$ is the pull-back $C=\mathfrak{C}_{g,|\varsigma|} \times_{\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}} S \rightarrow S$. The functoriality of Olsson's log stack implies that $S \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}$ factors through a unique strict morphism $S \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }$ such that the family $C \rightarrow S$ is the pull-back $C=\mathfrak{C}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log } \times_{\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }} S \rightarrow S$. In particular, we obtain a tautological morphism

$$
\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta) \longrightarrow \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }, \quad[f: C / S \rightarrow X] \mapsto[C / S]
$$

which assigns to a log map its domain log curve.
2.2.1. Deformations of log maps relative to $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }$. Suppose $S$ is a geometric log point of $\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta)$ corresponding to a $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$. The first-order deformations and obstructions of the log map relative to $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }$ are controlled by $H^{0}\left(f^{*} T_{X}\right)$ and $H^{1}\left(f^{*} T_{X}\right)$ respectively ([ACGS21, §4]). In particular, the expected relative dimension at $[f]$ is

$$
\exp \operatorname{dim}_{[f]}\left(\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta) / \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log }\right)=\chi\left(f^{*} T_{X}\right)
$$

yielding the expected dimension

$$
\exp \operatorname{dim}_{[f]}\left(\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta)\right)=\chi\left(f^{*} T_{X}\right)+3 g-3+|\varsigma|
$$

Example 2.4 (Toric example). Let $X$ be the log scheme associated to a toric variety with its toric boundary. Then $T_{X} \cong \mathcal{O}^{\oplus \operatorname{dim} X}$ by [CLS11, Theorem 8.1.1]. For any genus zero log map $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow X$ over a geometric log point $S$, we have $H^{1}\left(f^{*} T_{X}\right)=0$. This implies that the tautological morphism (2.2) is log smooth. Consequently $\mathscr{M}_{0, \varsigma}(X, \beta)$ is also log smooth of dimension

$$
\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathscr{M}_{0, \varsigma}(X, \beta)\right)=\operatorname{dim} X+|\varsigma|-3
$$

2.2.2. Deformations of log maps relative to Log. The morphism of log stacks $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec} \mathbf{k}$ induces a tautological morphism

$$
\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}^{\log } \longrightarrow \mathbf{L o g}:=\mathbf{L o g}_{\text {Speck }}, \quad[C \rightarrow S] \mapsto[S]
$$

hence a tautological morphism by composing (2.2)

$$
\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta) \longrightarrow \mathbf{L o g}, \quad[f: C / S \rightarrow X] \mapsto[S]
$$

For a $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$ over $S$, consider the complex $N_{f}$ defined by the distinguished triangle

$$
T_{C / S} \xrightarrow{d f} T_{X} \longrightarrow N_{f} \xrightarrow{[1]}
$$

Suppose $S$ is a geometric log point. The first-order deformations and obstructions of $[f]$ relative to Log are controlled by $H^{0}\left(N_{f}\right)$ and $H^{1}\left(N_{f}\right)$ respectively. In general $N_{f}$ is a complex rather than a sheaf. We call $N_{f}$ the normal complex of $f$.
2.3. The deformation theory of log immersions. We describe a situation where the complex $N_{f}$ is represented by a vector bundle. This will allow us to effectively compute deformations of log maps in many examples.
Definition 2.5. Let $f: C \rightarrow X$ be a log map over a geometric log point $S$. We say that $f$ is a log immersion if
(1) For any node or marking $p \in C$ with contact order $\mathbf{c}_{p}$, we have $\mathbf{c}_{p} \neq 0$ and char $\mathbf{k} \nmid \mathbf{c}_{p}$.
(2) The underlying morphism $\underline{f}: \underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ is an immersion away from nodes and markings.

Condition (1) implies the images of all nodes and markings are necessarily in $\Delta$. The following is a generalization of [CZ19, Lemma 4.12] with a similar proof. We provide a detailed proof for completeness.

Lemma 2.6. Suppose $f: C \rightarrow X$ is a log immersion. Then $d f: T_{C / S} \rightarrow f^{*} T_{X}$ is injective as a subbundle. Hence the cokernel $N_{f}:=\operatorname{Cok} d f$ is a vector bundle on $C$.
Proof. It suffices to prove dually that $f^{*}: f^{*} \Omega_{X} \rightarrow \Omega_{C / S}$ is surjective and the kernel is locally free. We verify this locally around a closed point $x \in C$.
Case 1: Smooth non-marked points. Suppose $x$ is a smooth non-marked point. Let $Z \subset C$ be the irreducible component containing $x$. For a subset $J \subset\{i\}$, denote by $\underline{X}_{J}^{\circ}:=\left(\cap_{j \in J} \Delta_{j}\right) \backslash \cup_{i \notin J} \Delta_{i}$, and set $\underline{X}_{\emptyset}^{\circ}=\underline{X} \backslash \Delta$ for $J=\emptyset$. Thus $\left\{\underline{X}_{J}^{\circ} \mid \underline{X}_{J}^{\circ} \neq \emptyset\right\}$ is a stratification of $\underline{X}$ such that $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{X} \mid \underline{X}_{J}^{\circ}$ is the trivial monoid $\mathbb{N}^{|J|}$. Let $Z^{\circ} \subset Z$ be the open subscheme obtained by removing all nodes and markings. It contains $x$. Then there is a unique stratum $\underline{X}_{J}^{\circ} \neq \emptyset$ such that the underlying morphism $\left.\underline{f}\right|_{\underline{Z}^{\circ}}: \underline{Z}^{\circ} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ factors through $\underline{X}_{J}^{\circ}$. Thus the induced $\underline{Z}^{\circ} \rightarrow \underline{X}_{J}^{\circ}$ is an immersion in the usual sense. We have a commutative diagram
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)
where the top is an exact sequence by [CZ19, Lemma 4.13] and $\Omega_{\underline{X}_{J}}$ is the cotangent bundle of the underlying scheme. The immersion $\underline{Z}^{\circ} \rightarrow \underline{X}_{J}^{\circ}$ implies the surjectivity of $\left.f^{*}\right|_{\underline{Z}^{\circ}}$ as needed. Moreover the kernel is locally free in a neighborhood of $x$ because $\left.\Omega_{X}\right|_{\underline{Z}^{\circ}}$ is torsion free and $x$ is a smooth point of $\underline{C}$.
Case 2: Marked points. Let $x$ be a marked point, defined by a local coordinate $z$. Thus the fiber $\omega_{C / S} \mid x$ is generated by a section $\frac{d z}{z}$. Let $\underline{X}_{J}$ be the unique stratum containing the image $f(x)$. Thus the fiber $\left.\Omega_{X}\right|_{x}$ contains a set of linearly independent vectors $\left\{\left.\frac{d \delta_{j}}{\delta_{j}}\right|_{x} \mid j \in J\right\}$, where $\delta_{j}$ are defining equations of $\Delta_{j}$ locally around $f(x)$. Let $\mathbf{c}_{x}$ be the contact order at $x$; we write it in the form $\mathbf{c}_{x}=\left(c_{x, j}\right)_{j \in J}$ where the contact order at $x$ along $\Delta_{j}$ is given by $c_{x, j} \in \mathbb{N}$. By assumption, there exists $j \in J$ such that $c_{x, j}>0$ and char $\mathbf{k} \nmid c_{x, j}$. Thus, by an appropriate choice of coordinates, we have $f^{*}\left(\left.\frac{d \delta_{j}}{\delta_{j}}\right|_{x}\right)=c_{x, j} \cdot \frac{d z}{z} \neq 0$. Hence $\left.f^{*}\right|_{x}$ is surjective. As $f^{*}$ is a morphism of coherent sheaves, this implies the surjectivity of $f^{*}$ in a neighborhood of $x$. Again the kernel is locally free because $x$ is a smooth point of $\underline{C}$.
Case 3: Nodal points. Suppose $x$ is a node. Similar to the case of marked points, it suffices to prove the surjectivity of $\left.f^{*}\right|_{x}$ and local freeness of the kernel on a neighborhood of $x$. Suppose $x$ is a node joining two branches $Z_{1}$ and $Z_{2}$ with local coordinates $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$. Then $\left.\omega_{C / S}\right|_{x}$ is generated by a local section $\frac{d z_{1}}{z_{1}}=-\frac{d z_{2}}{z_{2}}$. Again let $\underline{X}_{J}$ be the unique stratum containing the image $f(x)$. Thus the fiber $\left.\Omega_{X}\right|_{x}$ contains a set of linearly independent vectors $\left\{\left.\frac{d \delta_{j}}{\delta_{j}}\right|_{x} \mid j \in J\right\}$ where each $\delta_{j}$ is the defining equation of $\Delta_{j}$ locally around $f(x)$. Let $\mathbf{c}_{x}$ be the contact order at the node $x$. (The definition was given just before Notation 2.3.) This means that for each $j \in J$, one of the two branches $Z_{i}$ has contact order $c_{x, j} \in \mathbb{N}$ along $\Delta_{j}$ at $x$. The assumption on contact orders implies that there is a $j \in J$ and an $i \in\{1,2\}$ such that $Z_{i}$ has contact order $c_{x, j}>0$ along $\Delta_{j}$ such that char $\mathbf{k} \nmid c_{x, j}$. Similarly, by an appropriate

choice of coordinates, we have $f^{*}\left(\left.\frac{d \delta_{j}}{\delta_{j}}\right|_{x}\right)=c_{x, j} \cdot \frac{d z_{i}}{z_{i}} \neq 0$. This implies the desired surjectivity of $\left.f^{*}\right|_{x}$. Furthermore, an element $\sum_{j \in J} a_{j}\left.\frac{d \delta_{j}}{\delta_{j}}\right|_{x}$ lies in the kernel of $\left.f^{*}\right|_{x}$ if it satisfies the linear relation $\sum_{j \in J} c_{x, j} a_{j}=0$. Thus the kernel has codimension 1 so that it is locally free at $x$.

Consider a $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$ over a $\log$ point $S$. There is a natural associated log map $\bar{f}: \bar{C} \rightarrow X$ over $S$ such that the composition $C \longrightarrow \bar{C} \longrightarrow X$ is $f$ where the first arrow is the forgetful morphism removing all markings with the zero contact order. In particular, $\bar{f}$ is a log map with only contact markings.

Corollary 2.7. Notations as above, further assume that $\bar{f}$ is a log immersion and let $P$ denote the set of non-contact markings of $f$. Then $N_{f}$ is a sheaf with torsion-free part $N_{f}^{t f}=N_{\bar{f}}$ and torsion $N_{f}^{\text {tor }}=\oplus_{k \in P} N_{p_{k} / \underline{C}}$.
Proof. Consider the following diagram whose rows are distinguished triangles:
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

The injectivity of $T_{C / S} \rightarrow T_{\bar{C} / S}$ and Lemma 2.6 imply that $T_{C / S} \rightarrow f^{*} T_{X}$ is injective. Hence $N_{f}$ is a sheaf. By Lemma 2.6 again, $N_{\bar{f}}$ is locally free. The kernel-cokernel sequence shows that the kernel of $N_{f} \rightarrow N_{\bar{f}}$ can be identified with the cokernel of the leftmost map, namely $\oplus_{k \in P} N_{p_{k} / \underline{C}}$. This implies our assertion.
2.4. Deformations of log maps with point constraints. For a subset $P \subset\{1, \cdots,|\varsigma|\}$ and a collection of points $q_{k} \in X^{\circ}:=X \backslash \Delta$ for $k \in P$, we introduce the point constraint

$$
f_{P}:=\left\{p_{k} \mapsto q_{k} \mid k \in P\right\}
$$

sending the $k$-th marking to $q_{k}$. A $\log$ map $f$ satisfies the point constraint $f_{P}$ iff $f\left(p_{k}\right)=q_{k}$ for $k \in P$. As $q_{k} \in X^{\circ}$, we necessarily have $\mathbf{c}_{k}=0$.

For each $k \in P$, consider the evaluation morphism

$$
\mathrm{ev}_{k}: \mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta) \longrightarrow \underline{X}, \quad[f] \mapsto f\left(p_{k}\right)
$$

induced by the $k$-th marking. The moduli of stable log maps satisfying the point constraint $f_{P}$ is

$$
\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}\left(X, \beta, f_{P}\right):=\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta) \times \prod_{P} \underline{X} \prod_{k \in P} q_{k}
$$

with $\prod_{k \in P} \mathrm{ev}_{k}: \mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(X, \beta) \rightarrow \prod_{P} \underline{X}$.
Consider a $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$ over $S$ satisfying the point constraint $f_{P}$. As $\mathbf{c}_{k}=0$ for $k \in P$, by removing $\left\{p_{k} \mid k \in P\right\}$ from the set of markings, $f$ induces an associated log map $\bar{f}: \bar{C} \rightarrow X$ over $S$ such that $f$ is given by the composition $C \rightarrow \bar{C} \rightarrow X$. Consider the twisted normal complex

$$
N_{f, f_{P}}:=N_{\bar{f}}\left(-\sum_{k \in P} p_{k}\right)
$$

Assuming that $S$ is a geometric log point, then the first order deformations and obstructions of $f$ relative to $\log$ are given by $H^{0}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right)$ and $H^{1}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right)$ respectively ([ACGS21, §4]).
2.5. Deformation of log maps relative to codimension 1 boundary. The condition Definition 2.5.(1) leads to a very intuitive geometric picture around contact markings as observed below.

Lemma 2.8. Let $f: C \rightarrow X$ be a log map (not necessarily a log immersion) over a geometric log point $S$. Suppose $p \in C$ is a marking satisfying char $\mathbf{k} \nmid \mathbf{c}_{p}$. Further assume that the image $x=f(p)$ is contained in a unique boundary component $\Delta_{i} \subset \Delta$. Then there is a natural isomorphism

$$
\left.T_{\Delta_{i}}\right|_{x} \cong\left.N_{f}\right|_{p}
$$

Proof. We have the following commutative diagram of solid arrows at $p$ :
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)
where the middle row is the pull-back of (2.5) to $p$ and the two columns are obtained by pulling back corresponding exact sequences in [CZ14, Lemma 4.1]. The same calculation as in Lemma 2.6, case 2 shows that $d f$ is non-zero, inducing the isomorphism $\mathcal{O}_{p} \cong \mathcal{O}_{p}$. Consequently, we obtain the two dashed arrows, finishing the proof.

Consider the moduli $\mathscr{M}_{g, \lambda}\left(X, \beta, f_{P}\right)$ as in (2.6). Let $p_{k}$ be a contact marking such that $k \notin P$. Further assume there is an $i^{\prime}$ such that char $\mathbf{k} \nmid c_{k, i^{\prime}} \neq 0$, and $c_{k, i}=0$ for all $i \neq i^{\prime}$. This induces an evaluation morphism

$$
\operatorname{ev}_{k}: \mathscr{M}_{g, \lambda}\left(X, \beta, f_{P}\right) \rightarrow \Delta_{i^{\prime}}
$$

We are interested in the local structure of this morphism along the stratum $\Delta_{i^{\prime}}^{\circ}=\Delta_{i^{\prime}} \backslash \cup_{i \neq i^{\prime}} \Delta_{i}$.
Proposition 2.9. Consider a log map $[f: C \rightarrow X] \in \mathscr{M}_{g, \lambda}^{\circ}\left(X, \beta, f_{P}\right)(S)$ over a geometric log point $S$ such that $x=f\left(p_{k}\right) \in \Delta_{i^{\prime}}^{\circ}$. Then there is a natural morphism

$$
\left.d \operatorname{ev}_{k}\right|_{[f]}: H^{0}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right) \rightarrow\left.T_{\Delta_{i^{\prime}}}\right|_{x}
$$

It is surjective if $H^{1}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\left(-p_{k}\right)\right)=0$.
Proof. Consider the exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{C}\left(-p_{k}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{p_{k}} \rightarrow 0
$$

Tensoring with $N_{f, f_{P}}$, we obtain a distinguished triangle

$$
N_{f, f_{P}}\left(-p_{k}\right) \rightarrow N_{f, f_{P}} \rightarrow N_{f, f_{P}}\left.\right|_{p_{k}} \stackrel{11}{\rightarrow}
$$

Taking the long exact sequence of cohomology, we have

$$
H^{0}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\left(-p_{k}\right)\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f, f_{P}} p_{k}\right) \rightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\left(-p_{k}\right)\right)
$$

Then $d \mathrm{ev}_{k}^{\circ}| | f \mid$ is given by the composition

$$
H^{0}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f, f_{P}} p_{k}\right) \cong T_{\Delta_{i}} \mid x
$$

with the isomorphism given by Lemma 2.8. When $H^{1}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\left(-p_{k}\right)\right)=0$ surjectivity follows from the long exact sequence.
2.6. Log gluing along markings. We provide a gluing construction of log maps that can increase contact orders at a given marking. Similar constructions for $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-curves in different settings were provided in $[\mathrm{CZ} 15, \S 4]$ and $[\mathrm{CZ} 18, \S 4]$.

Suppose that for each $j=1,2$, we have a $\log \operatorname{map} f_{j}: C_{j} \rightarrow X$ over a geometric log point $S_{i}$, and a marking $p_{j} \in C_{j}$ with contact order $\mathbf{c}_{p_{j}}$ contained in an irreducible component $Z_{j} \subset C_{j}$ such that

$$
\underline{S}_{1}=\underline{S}_{2}, \quad \text { and } \quad f_{1}\left(p_{1}\right)=f_{2}\left(p_{2}\right)
$$

Set $x=f_{i}\left(p_{i}\right) \in X$. We further assume that $f_{j}\left(Z_{j}\right) \not \subset \Delta_{\text {red }}$ for $j=1,2$. For later use, let $M_{j}$ denote the set of markings on $C_{j}$.

In the following subsections we describe how to construct a log stable map $f: C \rightarrow X$ that restricts to the maps $f_{1}, f_{2}$ along certain irreducible components of $C$. The construction depends on how the intersection point $x$ interacts with the irreducible components of the boundary divisor. We only describe the construction when $x$ lies on at most one irreducible component.
2.6.1. Gluing along non-degenerate point. First, we assume that $x \in X^{\circ}$. In particular $\mathbf{c}_{p_{1}}=\mathbf{c}_{p_{2}}=0$. To glue $f_{1}$ and $f_{2}$ along $p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$, we first construct the glued underlying pre-stable map $\underline{f}: \underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ such that $\underline{C}=\underline{C}_{1} \cup_{p_{1}=p_{2}} \underline{C}_{2}$ is obtained by identifying $p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$, and $\left.\underline{f}\right|_{\underline{C}_{j}}=\underline{f}_{j}$ for each $j$.

Let $M$ be the set of markings on the new prestable curve $\underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{S}$. It is given by

$$
M:=\left(M_{1} \backslash\left\{p_{1}\right\}\right) \sqcup\left(M_{2} \backslash\left\{p_{2}\right\}\right)
$$

Note that $p_{1}, p_{2}$ are glued to a node, denoted by $p$. Let $C^{\sharp} \rightarrow S^{\sharp}$ be the canonical log curve over $\underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{S}$ taking into account all markings. Similarly, let $C_{j}^{\sharp} \rightarrow S_{j}^{\sharp}$ be the canonical log curve over $\underline{C}_{j} \rightarrow \underline{S}_{j}$. Over the same underlying point $\underline{S}$, we have a splitting

$$
\mathcal{M}_{S^{\sharp}}=\mathcal{M}_{S_{1}^{\sharp}} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\circ}} \mathcal{N}_{p} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\circ}} \mathcal{M}_{S_{2}^{\sharp}}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}_{p}$ is the canonical log structure smoothing the node $p$.
Recall that the stable $\log \operatorname{map} C_{j} \rightarrow S_{j}$ is equivalent to a morphism of log structures $\mathcal{M}_{S_{j}^{\sharp}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{S_{j}}$, i.e., this means that $C_{j} \rightarrow S_{j}$ is isomorphic to $C_{j}^{\sharp} \times_{S_{j}^{\sharp}} S_{j} \rightarrow S_{j}$. We then define the $\log$ point $S$ by setting

$$
\mathcal{M}_{S}:=\mathcal{M}_{S_{1}} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\circ}} \mathcal{N}_{p} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\circ}} \mathcal{M}_{S_{2}}
$$

The morphism of $\log$ structures $\mathcal{M}_{S^{\sharp}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{S}$ induced by $\mathcal{M}_{S_{j}^{\sharp}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{S_{j}}$ and the identity $\mathcal{N}_{p} \rightarrow$ $\mathcal{N}_{p}$ defines a morphism of $\log$ points $S \rightarrow S^{\sharp}$. We obtain the $\log$ curve $C:=C^{\sharp} \times_{S^{\sharp}} S \rightarrow S$.

Finally, $\underline{f}$ lifts to a stable $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$ such that the restriction $\left.f\right|_{\underline{C}_{j}}$ is induced by $f_{j}$ naturally. Note that for every marking $p^{\prime} \in C$ its contact order is the same as the contact order of the corresponding marking from $f_{j}$.
2.6.2. Gluing along markings in codimension 1 boundary strata. Now we assume that there is an index $i$ such that $x \in \Delta_{i^{\prime}}$ iff $i^{\prime}=i$. In particular, $x$ is contained in the unique codimension 1 boundary stratum of $\Delta_{i}$. For simplicity we will write $c_{p_{1}}$ and $c_{p_{2}}$ for the unique non-zero element in the contact orders $\mathbf{c}_{p_{1}}$ and $\mathbf{c}_{p_{2}}$.
Step 1. The underlying pre-stable map. To glue $f_{1}$ and $f_{2}$, we introduce a smooth rational curve $\underline{I}$ with three distinct special points $p_{1}^{\prime}, p_{2}^{\prime}, p$. We form the underlying pre-stable curve over $\underline{S}$

$$
\underline{C}=\underline{C}_{1} \cup_{p_{1}=p_{1}^{\prime}} \underline{I} \cup_{p_{2}^{\prime}=p_{2}} \underline{C}_{2}
$$

by the corresponding identifications. Denote by $q_{j}$ the node obtained by gluing $p_{j}$ and $p_{j}^{\prime}$. The set of markings on $\underline{C}$ is given by

$$
M:=\left(M_{1} \backslash\left\{p_{1}\right\}\right) \sqcup\{p\} \sqcup\left(M_{2} \backslash\left\{p_{2}\right\}\right)
$$

The glued underlying pre-stable map $\underline{f}: \underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ is defined by

$$
\left.\underline{f}\right|_{\underline{C}_{j}}:=\underline{f}_{j} \quad \text { and } \quad \underline{f}(\underline{I})=x
$$

Step 2. The domain log curve. Next, we construct a stable $\log$ map $C \rightarrow S$ over the underlying curve $\underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{S}$ as follows. Let $C^{\sharp} \rightarrow S^{\sharp}$ be the canonical log curve over $\underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{S}$ with the set of markings $M$. There is a splitting

$$
\mathcal{M}_{S^{\sharp}}=\mathcal{M}_{S_{1}^{\sharp}} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\times}} \mathcal{N}_{q_{1}} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\times}} \mathcal{N}_{q_{2}} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\times}} \mathcal{M}_{S_{2}^{\sharp}}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}_{q_{j}}$ is the canonical log structure on $\underline{S}$ smoothing the node $q_{j}$, and $\mathcal{M}_{S_{j}^{\sharp}}$ is the canonical log structure associated to the underlying curve $\underline{C}_{j} \rightarrow \underline{S}$ as above.

Since $\underline{S}$ is a geometric point, we have a (non-canonical) splitting

$$
\mathcal{N}_{q_{j}} \cong \mathbb{N} \times \mathcal{O}_{\underline{S}}^{\times}
$$

Define a new $\log$ structure $\mathcal{N}:=\mathbb{N} \times \mathcal{O}_{\underline{S}}^{\times}$with the structure arrow $\alpha: \mathcal{N} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\underline{S}}$ such that $\alpha(n, u)=0$ if $n>0$ and $\alpha(n, u)=u$ if $n=0$. Set $\ell=\operatorname{lcm}\left(c_{p_{1}}, c_{p_{2}}\right)^{1}$. We fix a morphism of $\log$ structures for each $j$

$$
\mathcal{N}_{q_{j}} \longrightarrow \mathcal{N}, \quad(n, u) \mapsto\left(n \cdot \ell / c_{p_{j}}, u\right)
$$

We then define $S$ to be the geometric log point with log structure

$$
\mathcal{M}_{S}:=\mathcal{M}_{S_{1}} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\times}} \mathcal{N} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\times}} \mathcal{M}_{S_{2}}
$$

This leads to a morphism of log structures

$$
\mathcal{M}_{S^{\sharp}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{S}
$$

induced by $\mathcal{M}_{S_{j}^{\sharp}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{S_{j}}$ and the fixed morphism $\mathcal{N}_{q_{j}} \rightarrow \mathcal{N}$ above, hence a morphism of log points $S \rightarrow S^{\sharp}$. This defines a morphism of log points $S \rightarrow S^{\sharp}$, hence a log curve

$$
C:=C^{\sharp} \times_{S^{\sharp}} S \rightarrow S
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ In case $c_{p_{1}}=c_{p_{2}}=0$, we may set $\ell=1$ and the following construction still works.

Step 3. The log map defined over $C \backslash L^{\circ}$. Denote by $L \subset C$ the closed strict subscheme over $\underline{L}$ and let $L^{\circ}=L \backslash\left\{q_{1}, q_{2}\right\}$. Then we have $C \backslash L=C_{1}^{\circ} \sqcup C_{2}^{\circ}$ where $\underline{C}_{j}^{\circ}=\underline{C}_{j} \backslash\left\{p_{j}\right\}$. The construction of $C \rightarrow S$ implies that

$$
\mathcal{M}_{C_{j}^{\circ}}=\left.\mathcal{M}_{C_{j}}\right|_{\underline{C_{j}^{\circ}}} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\times}} \mathcal{N} \oplus_{\mathcal{O}^{\times}} \mathcal{M}_{S_{j^{\prime}}}
$$

where $j^{\prime} \neq j$. Thus we naturally define

$$
\left.f\right|_{C_{j}^{\circ}}:=\left.f_{j}\right|_{\underline{C_{j}^{\circ}}}: C_{j}^{\circ} \rightarrow X
$$

for $j=1,2$.
Further recall that $f_{j}\left(Z_{j}\right) \not \subset \Delta_{\text {red }}$, i.e. $\left.f\right|_{Z_{j}}$ intersects the boundary $\Delta$ properly at $q_{j}$. We observe that $\left.f\right|_{C_{j}^{\circ}}$ extends uniquely across the node $q_{j}$ to yield a morphism

$$
\left.f\right|_{\overline{C_{1}^{\circ} \cup C_{2}^{\circ}}}: \overline{C_{1}^{\circ} \sqcup C_{2}^{\circ}} \rightarrow X
$$

where $\overline{C_{1}^{\circ} \sqcup C_{2}^{\circ}}=C \backslash\left(L^{\circ}\right)$. To see this, let $s_{j}, t_{j}$ be the local coordinates around $q_{j}$ on the components $Z_{j}$ and $L$ respectively. They each lift uniquely to a local section of $\mathcal{M}_{C}$.

On the other hand, let $\delta$ be a local section of $\mathcal{O}_{X}$ around $x$ which is a local defining equation of $\Delta_{i}$. It lifts to a unique local section in $\mathcal{M}_{X}$ around $x$, denoted by $\delta$ again. Consequently, the pull-back log structure $\underline{f}^{*} \mathcal{M}_{X}$ around the point $q_{j}$ is generated by a unique section, denoted again by $\delta$. On the level of underlying morphisms, we have

$$
\underline{f}^{*}(\delta)=s_{j}^{c_{p_{j}}}
$$

by choosing coordinates properly. As morphisms of log schemes are required to be compatible with their underlying structures, on the level of log structures locally around $q_{j}$ we have

$$
f^{s}(\delta)=c_{p_{j}} \cdot s_{j}
$$

where the right hand side is written as additive monoids.
Step 4. Extending the log map to $L \backslash\left\{q_{1}, q_{2}\right\}$. To construct an $f$ over $C$, it remains to construct $\left.f\right|_{L}: L \rightarrow X$ which is compatible with (2.8) at the two nodes $q_{1}, q_{2}$. More precisely, as $\underline{f}(\underline{L})=x, \underline{f}^{*} \mathcal{M}_{X} \mid{ }_{L}$ is generated by the element $\delta$. To define $\left.f\right|_{L}$, it suffices to find $f^{s}(\delta) \in \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid L$ whose fibers at the two nodes agree with (2.9).

We wish to construct the dotted arrows in the following diagram
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
where the middle and right vertical arrows are the quotient by $\mathcal{O}_{\underline{L}}^{\times}$, and the left square is Cartesian. The above discussion implies that $\underline{f}^{*}\left(\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{X}\right) \mid \underline{L}=\mathbb{N}_{\underline{L}}$ is the constant sheaf with the generator $\bar{\delta}$ which is the image of $\delta$. Furthermore $\mathcal{T}$ is a trivial $\mathcal{O}^{\times}$-torsor.

We first define $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}$ by specifying the element $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta}) \in \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid \underline{L}$. Recall that $t_{j}, s_{j}$ denote local coordinates at the node $q_{j}$ of $L, Z_{j}$ respectively. Denote by $\bar{t}_{j}, \bar{s}_{j}$ the images of $t_{j}, s_{j}$ in the characteristic sheaf respectively. Let $t$ be the local coordinate of $p$ which lifts uniquely to a local section of $\left.\mathcal{M}_{C}\right|_{\underline{L}}$, again denoted by $t$. Let $\bar{t}$ be the image of $t$ in the characteristic sheaf.

Note that $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid \underline{L}$ is constructible with respect to the following strata

$$
q_{1}, \quad q_{2}, \quad p, \quad \underline{L} \backslash\left\{q_{1}, q_{2}, p\right\}
$$

along which $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C}$ becomes sheaves of constant monoids. Let $e$ be the generator of $\overline{\mathcal{N}}$. We define the image $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta})$ along each stratum as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta})\left.\right|_{q_{j}}:=c_{p_{j}} \cdot \bar{s}_{j}, \quad \text { for } j=1,2 \\
& \left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta})\left.\right|_{p}:=\ell \cdot e+\left(c_{p_{1}}+c_{p_{2}}\right) \cdot \bar{t} \\
& \left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta})\left.\right|_{\underline{L} \backslash\left\{q_{1}, q_{2}, p\right\}}:=\ell \cdot e
\end{aligned}
$$

We observe that the above assignments glue to an element $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta}) \in \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid \underline{L}$. First note that the element $\left(\ell \cdot e+\left(c_{p_{1}}+c_{p_{2}}\right) \cdot \bar{t}\right)$ generates to $\ell \cdot e$ since the element $\bar{t}$ is 0 when restricted away from $p$.

To verify that the above construction glues across $\underline{q_{1}}$ and $q_{2}$, it suffices to show that $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta})$ is well-defined in the constructible sheaf of groups $\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C}^{\text {sp }} \mid \underline{L}$, as all the monoids involved are fine and saturated. By the construction in Step 2, we have

$$
\ell / c_{p_{j}} \cdot e=\bar{s}_{j}+\bar{t}_{j}
$$

hence

$$
c_{p_{j}} \cdot \bar{s}_{j}=c_{p_{j}} \cdot\left(\ell / c_{p_{j}} \cdot e-\bar{t}_{j}\right)=\ell \cdot e-c_{p_{j}} \cdot \bar{t}_{j} \quad \text { in } \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C, q_{j}}^{s p}
$$

Note that $\bar{t}_{j}$ is 0 when away from $q_{j}$. This shows that $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta}) \in \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid \underline{L}$ is a well-defined section on $\underline{L}$, hence a well-defined morphism on the characteristic level $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}:\underline{f}^{*} \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{X} \rightarrow \overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid L$.

Consider the $\mathcal{O}^{\times}$-torsor $\mathcal{T}^{\prime}:=\left.\mathcal{M}_{C}\right|_{\underline{L}} \times_{\overline{\mathcal{M}}_{C} \mid \underline{L}}\left\{\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}(\bar{\delta})\right\}$. To lift $\left.\bar{f}^{s}\right|_{L}$ to a morphism of $\log$ structures $\left.f^{s}\right|_{L}:\underline{f}^{*} \mathcal{M}_{X} \mid \underline{L} \rightarrow\left.\mathcal{M}_{C}\right|_{\underline{L}}$, it suffices to find an isomorphism of $\mathcal{O}^{\times}$-torsors $\mathcal{T} \xrightarrow{\cong} \mathcal{T}^{\prime}$. Recall that $\mathcal{T}$ is a trivial torsor. On the other hand, (2.10) and (2.11) implies that $\mathcal{T}^{\prime}$ consists of sections with poles of order $c_{p_{j}}$ at $q_{j}$ and zeros of order $c_{p_{1}}+c_{p_{2}}$ at $p$, and no other poles and zeros. In particular, $\mathcal{T}^{\prime}$ is also trivial. Thus, any isomorphism $\mathcal{T} \cong \mathcal{T}^{\prime}$ defines the morphism $f^{s}$, hence a $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$ over $S$ as needed.
2.7. Smoothing of the log gluing. Let $f: C \rightarrow X$ over $S$ be constructed as in Section 2.6.2. We further impose point constraints $f_{P_{j}}$ for $f_{j}$ as in $\S 2.4$. This leads to point constraints $f_{P}=f_{P_{1}} \cup f_{P_{2}}$ for $f$. We next study the deformation of $f$ with the constraints $f_{P}$, and prove the following sufficient condition for smoothing $f$ (and in particular smoothing the two nodes $\left.q_{1}, q_{2}\right)$.

Proposition 2.10. Notation as above. Suppose that $c_{p_{1}}, c_{p_{2}}, c_{p}=\left(c_{p_{1}}+c_{p_{2}}\right)$ are coprime to char $\mathbf{k}$, the restrictions $H^{0}\left(N_{f_{j}, f_{P_{j}}}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f_{j}, f_{P_{j}}} \mid p_{j}\right) \cong\left.T_{\Delta}\right|_{x}$ are surjective (see Lemma 2.8), and $H^{1}\left(N_{f_{j}, f_{P_{j}}}\right)=0$. Then we have $H^{1}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right)=0$. In particular, a general deformation of $f$ with the point constraints $f_{P}$ is non-degenerate.

Proof. Note that $H^{1}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right)=0$ implies $f$ is unobstructed relative to Log, see $\S 2.4$. Thus, a general deformation of $f$ is a log map over a point with the trivial log structure, i.e. non-degenerate. Thus the last sentence of the statement follows from the earlier claims.

For the rest of this statement, we will assume that $f_{P}=\emptyset$, hence $f_{P_{1}}=f_{P_{2}}=\emptyset$. The case with point constraints is identical but with slightly more complicated notations.

Consider the following distinguished triangle over $C$

$$
f^{*} \Omega_{X} \xrightarrow{f^{*}} \Omega_{C / S} \longrightarrow \mathbb{L}_{f} \xrightarrow{[1]}
$$

Taking duals and rotating the complex, we obtain a distinguished triangle as in (2.5)

$$
T_{C / S} \xrightarrow{d f} f^{*} T_{X} \longrightarrow \mathbb{L}_{f}^{\vee}[1] \xrightarrow{[1]}
$$

with $N_{f}=\mathbb{L}_{f}^{\vee}[1]$. We would like to compute $H^{1}\left(N_{f}\right)$.
Similarly we define $\mathbb{L}_{f_{j}}$ and $N_{f_{j}}=\mathbb{L}_{f_{j}}^{\vee}[1]$ over $C_{j}$ for $j=1,2$. It follows from the construction in Section 2.6.2 that $\left.\left(\mathbb{L}_{f}\right)\right|_{C_{j}} \cong \mathbb{L}_{f_{j}}$, hence $N_{f} \mid C_{j} \cong N_{f_{j}}$ for $j=1,2$.

To compute the cohomology of (2.13), consider the partial normalization sequence

$$
\pi: \tilde{C}:=C_{1} \sqcup L \sqcup C_{2} \rightarrow C
$$

hence a short exact sequence over $C$ :

$$
0 \longrightarrow \mathcal{O}_{C} \longrightarrow \pi_{*} \mathcal{O}_{\tilde{C}} \longrightarrow \mathcal{O}_{q_{1}} \oplus \mathcal{O}_{q_{2}} \longrightarrow 0
$$

Applying $\otimes N_{f}$ to the short exact sequence, and taking the corresponding long exact sequence, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f_{1}}\right) \oplus H^{0}\left(N_{f} \mid{ }_{L}\right) \oplus H^{0}\left(N_{f_{2}}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f} \mid q_{1}\right) \oplus H^{0}\left(N_{f} \mid q_{2}\right) \\
& \rightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{f}\right) \rightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{f_{1}}\right) \oplus H^{1}\left(N_{f} \mid{ }_{L}\right) \oplus H^{1}\left(N_{f_{2}}\right) \rightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{f} \mid q_{1}\right) \oplus H^{1}\left(N_{f} \mid q_{2}\right) \rightarrow \cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

To prove $H^{1}\left(N_{f}\right)=0$, we compute $\left.N_{f}\right|_{L}$ and $\left.N_{f}\right|_{q_{j}}$ and their cohomologies as follows. Consider $\left.\left(\mathbb{L}_{f}\right)\right|_{L}$ which fits in the distinguished triangle

$$
\left.f^{*} \Omega_{X}\right|_{L} \xrightarrow{f^{*}\left.\right|_{L}} \Omega_{C / S} \mid L \longrightarrow \mathbb{L}_{f} \mid L \xrightarrow{[1]}
$$

Since $f$ contracts the component $L$ to the point $x \in X$, we have $\left.f^{*} \Omega_{X}\right|_{L} \cong \mathcal{O}_{X}^{n}$ for $n=\operatorname{dim} X$ since $X$ is log smooth. Select local coordinates $y_{1}, \cdots, y_{n-1}, y_{n}$ in a neighborhood $U$ of $x$ such that $\Delta \cap U$ is defined by $y_{n}=0$. Then

$$
d y_{1}, \cdots, d y_{n-1}, d \log y_{n}
$$

form a basis of $\Omega_{X}$ locally around $x$. By abuse of notations, we view them as a basis of $\left.f^{*} \Omega_{X}\right|_{L}$. On the other hand, we observe that

$$
\left.\Omega_{C / S}\right|_{L}=\Omega_{\underline{L}}\left(q_{1}+q_{2}+p\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{L}(1)
$$

Since $L$ is contracted, we have $\left.f^{*}\right|_{L}\left(d y_{k}\right)=0$ for $k=1, \cdots n-1$.
Next we observe that $f_{L}^{*}\left(d \log y_{n}\right) \in H^{0}\left(\Omega_{C / S} \mid L\right)$ is a non-trivial section that vanishes at a point away from $q_{1}, q_{2}$ and $p$. Indeed, since the contact orders $c_{p_{1}}, c_{p_{2}}$, and $\left(c_{p_{1}}+c_{p_{2}}\right)$ are all prime to the characteristic of the ground field Equation (2.11) on the characteristic level implies that locally around $q_{j}$ we have

$$
\left.f^{*}\right|_{L}\left(d \log y_{n}\right)=u_{j} \cdot\left(-c_{p_{j}}\right) d \log t_{j}
$$

for some locally invertible function $u_{j}$, where $t_{j}$ is the local coordinate of $L$ around $q_{j}$ for $j=1,2$. And similarly around $p$ the second equation of (2.10) implies that

$$
\left.f^{*}\right|_{L}\left(d \log y_{n}\right)=u_{p} \cdot\left(c_{p_{1}}+c_{p_{2}}\right) d \log t
$$

for some locally invertible function $u_{p}$, where $t$ is the local coordinate of $L$ around $p$. As $d \log t_{1}, d \log t_{2}$, and $d \log t$ are local generators of $\left.\Omega_{C / S}\right|_{L}$ at $q_{1}, q_{2}$ and $p$ respectively, the section $\left.f^{*}\right|_{L}\left(d \log y_{n}\right)$ does not vanish at the three special points $q_{1}, q_{2}$, and $p$. Thus the

restriction of $\left.f^{*}\right|_{L}$ to the component $\mathcal{O}_{L} \cdot d \log y_{n} \subset f^{*}\left.\Omega_{X}\right|_{L}$ is an injection $\mathcal{O}_{L} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{L}(1) \cong$ $\left.\Omega_{C / S}\right|_{L}$. By degree considerations, the section $\left.f^{*}\right|_{L}\left(d \log y_{n}\right)$ vanishes at a point other than $q_{1}, q_{2}$, and $p$, say $p^{\prime}$.

Taking a dual, the above discussion implies that $\left.N_{f}\right|_{L}$ is the cone of the following complex

$$
\mathcal{O}_{L}(-1) \xrightarrow{d^{\prime}} \mathcal{O}_{L}^{\oplus n}
$$

In particular, we have $\left.N_{f}\right|_{L} \cong \mathcal{O}_{L}^{(n-1)} \oplus \mathcal{O}_{p^{\prime}}$. Noting that $y_{1}, \cdots, y_{n-1}$ form local coordinates of $\Delta$ around $x$, by further restricting to $q_{j}$ we have

$$
\left.N_{f}\right|_{q_{j}} \cong\left.T_{\Delta}\right|_{x} \cong \mathcal{O}_{q_{j}}^{\oplus(n-1)}
$$

for $j=1,2$. Thus we have the vanishing

$$
H^{1}\left(\left.N_{f}\right|_{q_{1}}\right)=0, \quad H^{1}\left(\left.N_{f}\right|_{q_{2}}\right)=0, \quad H^{1}\left(\left.N_{f}\right|_{L}\right)=0
$$

Finally, the statement follows from the above calculations and the long exact sequence, noting that $\left.N_{f_{j}}\right|_{p_{j}} \cong\left.N_{f}\right|_{q_{j}}$.
2.8. Splitting contact orders. Consider a log smooth variety $X$ with strict normal crossings boundary $\Delta=\cup_{i \in I} \Delta_{i}$ as above. Consider a non-zero contact order $\mathbf{c}_{\star}=\left(c_{\star, i}\right)$ at a marking, and denote by $I_{\star}=\left\{i \in I \mid c_{\star, i} \neq 0\right\}$ the set of non-vanishing components of $\mathbf{c}_{\star}$. The total splitting of $\mathbf{c}_{\star}$ is the collection of non-zero contact orders $\operatorname{split}\left(\mathbf{c}_{\star}\right):=\left\{\mathbf{u}_{k}=\left(u_{k, i}\right)\right\}_{k \in I_{\star}}$ where $u_{k, i}=0$ if $i \neq k$, and $u_{k, k}=c_{\star, k}$.
Proposition 2.11. Suppose that $f: C \rightarrow X$ is a non-degenerate, rational log map with contact orders $\varsigma=\left\{\mathbf{c}_{k}=\left(c_{k, i}\right)\right\}_{k}$ such that char $\mathbf{k} \nmid \mathbf{c}_{k}$ for all $k$, and point constraints $f_{P}$ at all non-contact markings. Let $\mathbf{c}_{\star} \in \varsigma$ be a non-zero contact order at the marked point $p_{\star}$ satisfying char $\mathbf{k} \nmid c_{\star, i}$ for all $i$ such that $c_{\star, i} \neq 0$. Assume $H^{1}\left(N_{f, f_{P}}\right)=0$. Then there is a non-degenerate, rational log map $\widetilde{f}: \widetilde{C} \rightarrow X$ with contact orders $\varsigma^{\prime}=\left\{\mathbf{c}_{k} \mid k \neq \star\right\} \cup \operatorname{split}\left(\mathbf{c}_{\star}\right)$ and curve class $f_{*}[C]$, satisfying the same point constraints $f_{P}$.

Remark 2.12. In the proof, we will construct a degenerate $\log \operatorname{map} \widetilde{f}_{0}: \widetilde{C}_{0} \rightarrow X$ over $S$ with contact orders $\varsigma^{\prime}$ and point constraints $f_{P}$ such that $H^{1}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0}, f_{P}}\right)=0$ and $f: C \rightarrow X$ appears as one of its components. Then $\widetilde{f}$ is constructed as a general smoothing of $\widetilde{f}_{0}$. In some sense, $\widetilde{f}$ can be viewed as a "deformation" of $f$ that splits the contact order $\mathbf{c}_{\star}$. By upper semicontinuity of cohomologies of complexes of coherent sheaves which are flat over the base (see for example [Har12, Proposition 6.4]), we conclude that a general smoothing of $\widetilde{f}_{0}$ satisfies $H^{1}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}, f_{P}}\right)=0$.

Proof. We will assume in the proof that $f_{P}=\emptyset$. The general case is similar but with more complicated notation and is left to the readers.

Denote by $I_{\star}=\left\{i \in I \mid c_{\star, i} \neq 0\right\}$. If $\left|I_{\star}\right|=1$, then there is nothing to prove. So we assume $d:=\left|I_{\star}\right| \geq 2$. We split the proof into several steps.

Step 1: Construct a degenerate domain curve. Consider $\underline{R} \cong \mathbb{P}^{1}$ with a choice of distinct points $q_{\star}, q_{1}, q_{2}, \cdots, q_{\left|I_{\star}\right|} \in \underline{R}$. Let $\underline{\widetilde{C}}_{0}=\underline{C} \cup \underline{R}$ obtained by identifying $p_{\star} \in \underline{C}$ with $q_{\star} \in \underline{R}$. This pre-stable curve $\underline{\widetilde{C}}_{0}$ has the set of markings $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \neq \star} \cup\left\{q_{1}, q_{2}, \cdots, q_{\left|I_{\star}\right|}\right\}$. We obtain a $\log$ curve $\widetilde{C}_{0} \rightarrow S$ with the underlying pre-stable curve $\underline{\widetilde{C}}_{0}$ and its canonical log structure uniquely determined by its underlying structure.

Step 2: Construct a degenerate log map. Consider the stable map $\underline{\widetilde{f}}_{0}: \widetilde{\underline{C}}_{0} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ such that $\left.\underline{\widetilde{f}}_{0}\right|_{\underline{C}}=\underline{f}$ and $\underline{\widetilde{f}}_{0}(\underline{R})=\underline{f}\left(p_{\star}\right)$. We will lift $\underline{\widetilde{f}}_{0}$ to a stable log map $\widetilde{f}_{0}: \widetilde{C}_{0} \rightarrow X$ such that its contact orders at $\left\{q_{1}, q_{2}, \cdots, q_{\left|I_{\star}\right|}\right\}$ are given by $\operatorname{split}\left(\mathbf{c}_{\star}\right)=\left\{\mathbf{u}_{1}, \mathbf{u}_{2}, \cdots, \mathbf{u}_{\left|I_{\star}\right|}\right\}$, where $\mathbf{u}_{k}$ mean the non-trivial contact order with respect to $\Delta_{k}$.

For each $i \in I$, denote by $X_{i}$ the log scheme associated to the pair $\left(\underline{X}, \Delta_{i}\right)$. If $i \in I_{\star}$, we may apply [CZ14, Lemma 3.6] along the component $\underline{R}$ to obtain a stable $\log$ map $h_{i}: \widetilde{C}_{0} \rightarrow X_{i}^{\dagger}$ such that $q_{i}$ has contact order $\mathbf{c}_{\star, i}$. Here $X_{i}^{\dagger}$ is the specialization to normal cone of $\Delta_{i} \subset \underline{X}$ with its canonical log structure and a canonical projection $X_{i}^{\dagger} \rightarrow X_{i}$. Now let $\widetilde{f}_{0, i}$ be the stable log map given by the composition $\widetilde{C}_{0} \rightarrow X_{i}^{\dagger} \rightarrow X_{i}$.

If $i \notin I_{\star}$, since $\left.\underline{\widetilde{f}}_{0}\right|_{\underline{C}}=\underline{f}$ is non-degenerate, the underlying structure naturally induces a $\log \operatorname{map} \widetilde{f}_{0, i}: \widetilde{C}_{0} \rightarrow X_{i}$. Finally, we define

$$
\widetilde{f}_{0}:=\prod_{i \in I} \widetilde{f}_{0, i}: \widetilde{C}_{0} \rightarrow X=\prod_{i \in I} X_{i}
$$

where the product $\prod_{i \in I} X_{i}$ is taken over $\underline{X}$. Observe that $\widetilde{f}_{0}$ has contact orders $\varsigma^{\prime}$.
Step 3: Smoothing of the degenerate log map. We will show that $H^{1}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0}}\right)=0$. Hence $\widetilde{f}_{0}$ can be deformed to a non-degenerate log map with contact orders $\varsigma^{\prime}$. We work out the details following the same line of calculation as in Proposition 2.10.

Similar to (2.12) and (2.13), we have two triangles

$$
\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*} \Omega_{X} \xrightarrow{\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*}} \Omega_{\widetilde{C}_{0} / S} \longrightarrow \mathbb{L}_{\widetilde{f}_{0}} \xrightarrow{[1]}, \quad T_{\widetilde{C}_{0} / S} \xrightarrow{d \widetilde{f}_{0}} \widetilde{f}_{0}^{*} T_{X} \longrightarrow \mathbb{L}_{\widetilde{f}_{0}}^{\vee}[1] \xrightarrow{[1]},
$$

such that $\mathbb{L}_{\widetilde{f}_{0}}^{\vee}[1] \cong N_{\widetilde{f}_{0}}$. Using the normalization $\underline{C} \sqcup \underline{R} \rightarrow \widetilde{\underline{C}}_{0}$ and arguing as in Proposition 2.10, we obtain a long exact sequence

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0}}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{f}\right) \oplus H^{0}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0} \mid R}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0} \mid q_{\star}}\right) \\
& \rightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0}}\right) \rightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{f}\right) \oplus H^{1}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0} \mid R}\right) \rightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{\widetilde{f}_{0} \mid q_{\star}}\right) \rightarrow \cdots
\end{aligned}
$$

noting that $N_{f} \cong N_{\widetilde{f}_{0}} \mid C$. We next compute $\left.N_{\widetilde{f}_{0}}\right|_{R}$ and its cohomologies.
Select local coordinates $y_{1}, \cdots, y_{n-1}, y_{n}$ in a neighborhood $U$ of $f\left(p_{\star}\right)$ such that $\Delta_{i} \cap U$ is defined by $y_{i}=0$ for $i \in I_{\star}$. Then we have a basis of $\left.\Omega_{X}\right|_{U}$ :

$$
\left\{d y_{i}\left|i \notin I_{\star}\right\rangle \sqcup\left\{d \log y_{i}\left|i \in I_{\star}\right\rangle\right.\right\}
$$

By an abuse of notation, we view them as a basis of $\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*} \Omega_{X} \mid R$. Since $R$ is contracted, we obtain

$$
\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*} \Omega_{X} \mid R \cong \mathcal{O}_{R}^{\oplus n-\left|I_{\star}\right|} \oplus \mathcal{O}_{R}^{\oplus\left|I_{\star}\right|}
$$

given by the above choice of basis.
We also observe that $\Omega_{\widetilde{C}_{0} / S} \mid R=\Omega_{\underline{R}}\left(q_{\star}+\sum_{i \in I_{\star}} q_{i}\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{R}\left(\left|I_{\star}\right|-1\right)$. Since $R$ is contracted, we have $\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*}\left(\left.d y_{i}\right)\right|_{R}=0$ for $i \notin I_{\star}$. Furthermore, since char $\mathbf{k} \dagger c_{\star, i}$ for all $i$, we check that for each $i \in I_{\star}$ the section $\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*}\left(\left.d \log y_{i}\right)\right|_{R} \in \Omega_{\widetilde{C}_{0} / S} \mid R$ is a local generator at $q_{i}$, but is not a local generator at $q_{j}$ for $i \neq j$. Thus $\left\{\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*}\left(\left.d \log y_{i}\right)\right|_{R} \mid i \in I_{\star}\right\}$ form a basis of $H^{0}\left(\Omega_{\widetilde{C}_{0} / S} \mid R\right)$. In particular, the restriction $\left.\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*}\right|_{R}$ is a surjection of vector bundles

$$
\widetilde{f}_{0}^{*} \Omega_{X} \mid R \cong \mathcal{O}_{R}^{\oplus n-\left|I_{\star}\right|} \oplus \mathcal{O}_{R}^{\oplus\left|I_{\star}\right|} \rightarrow \Omega_{\widetilde{C}_{0} / S} \mid R \cong \mathcal{O}_{R}\left(\left|I_{\star}\right|-1\right)
$$

Taking duals, we obtain an exact sequence

$$
0 \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{R}\left(-|I_{*}|+1\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{R}^{\oplus n-|I_{*}|} \oplus \mathcal{O}_{R}^{\oplus\left|I_{*}\right|} \rightarrow N_{\tilde{f}_{0}} \mid{ }_{R} \rightarrow 0
$$

realizing $N_{\tilde{f}_{0}} \mid{ }_{R}$ as a semi-positive vector bundle over $R$. In particular, the restriction morphism $H^{0}\left(N_{\tilde{f}_{0}} \mid{ }_{R}\right) \rightarrow H^{0}\left(N_{\tilde{f}_{0}} \mid{ }_{0 *}\right)$ is surjective, and $H^{1}\left(N_{\tilde{f}_{0}} \mid{ }_{R}\right)=0$.

Finally applying the assumption $H^{1}\left(N_{f}\right)=0$ and the long exact sequence, we obtain $H^{1}\left(N_{\tilde{f}_{0}}\right)=0$ as needed.

# 3. Deformation theory for LOG SECTIONS 

In this section we analyze the sections of a morphism $\pi: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow B$ where $\mathcal{X}$ is a log scheme defined by a strict normal crossing divisor and $B$ is a curve. The main goal is to understand the moduli space and deformation theory of sections satisfying various properties.
3.1. Stable log sections and their stacks. Let $\mathcal{X}$ be a $\log$ scheme such that $\underline{\mathcal{X}}$ is smooth and the boundary divisor $\Delta \subset \underline{\mathcal{X}}$ is strict normal crossings. A flat, generically smooth, and projective morphism $\pi: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow B$ with connected fibers is called a log fibration if furthermore the restriction $\left.\pi\right|_{\Delta}: \Delta \rightarrow B$ is flat and generically relatively strict normal crossings. Here we will only consider the case that $B$ is a proper, smooth, genus $g$ curve equipped with the trivial log structure.

Let $S$ be a log point. A genus $g$ stable $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ over $S$ is called a stable log map of section type of $\pi$ if the curve class of the underlying pre-stable map of the composition $C \rightarrow \mathcal{X} \rightarrow B$ is $[B]$. It is further called a log section if $f$ is non-degenerate.

Denote by $\overline{\operatorname{sec}}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)$ the stack of stable log maps of section type for the log fibration $\pi: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow B$, and $\overline{\operatorname{sec}}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)^{+} \subset \overline{\operatorname{sec}}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)$ the open and closed substack parametrizing $\log$ maps with only contact markings. The open substacks

$$
\operatorname{Sec}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B) \subset \overline{\operatorname{Sec}}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B) \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)^{+} \subset \overline{\operatorname{Sec}}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)^{+}
$$

with the trivial log structure are the corresponding moduli stacks of log sections. Note that these open substacks are honest schemes. There is a decomposition into open and closed substacks

$$
\overline{\operatorname{sec}}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)=\bigsqcup_{(\varsigma, \beta)} \overline{\operatorname{Sec}}_{\varsigma}(\mathcal{X} / B, \beta)
$$

by further specifying the number of markings, contact orders $\varsigma$, and curve classes $\beta \in N_{1}(\mathcal{X})$ with $\pi_{*} \beta=[B]$. We observe that $\overline{\operatorname{Sec}}_{\varsigma}(\mathcal{X} / B, \beta)=\mathscr{M}_{g, \varsigma}(\mathcal{X}, \beta)$. Similarly we have

$$
\overline{\operatorname{Sec}}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)^{+}=\bigsqcup_{(\varsigma, \beta)} \overline{\operatorname{Sec}}_{\varsigma}(\mathcal{X} / B, \beta)
$$

is the union over $\varsigma$ without non-contact marking.
3.2. Deformations of stable log maps of section type. Let $[f] \in \overline{\operatorname{Sec}}_{\varsigma}(\mathcal{X} / B, \beta)(S)$ be an object over a $\log$ scheme $S$. Consider the commutative triangle
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

This induces a tautological morphism

$$
\overline{\operatorname{sec}}_{\varsigma}(\mathcal{X} / B, \beta) \rightarrow \mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}(B,[B])
$$

given by $[f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}] \mapsto[h: C \rightarrow B]$. Here $\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}(B,[B])$ is the Artin stack of $|\varsigma|$-marked, genus $g(B)$ pre-stable log maps to the target $B$ with curve class $[B]$. It fits in a commutative diagram with strict top arrows:
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)
where $\operatorname{Log}_{\bullet}$ is Olsson's log stack parametrizing log structures over a given log stack $\bullet$ as in $\S 2.2$.

Consider an object $[f] \in \overline{\operatorname{sec}}_{\varsigma}(\mathcal{X} / B, \beta)(S)$ as in (3.1) over a log point $S$. The normal complexes $N_{f}, N_{h}$ as in $\S 2.2$ fit in the following commutative diagram of distinguished triangles:
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

In particular, we have the triangle

$$
f^{*} T_{\mathcal{X} / B} \longrightarrow N_{f} \longrightarrow N_{h} \xrightarrow{[1]}
$$

By (2.5), we see that the cohomologies of $N_{f}$ and $N_{h}$ control the deformations of $f$ and $h$ relative to Log respectively.

Next, consider the deformations of (3.1) relative to $\operatorname{Log}_{\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}(B,[B])}$. These are deformations of $[f]$ while fixing $([h], S))$. In this case the first-order deformations and obstructions of (3.1) relative to $\operatorname{Log}_{\mathfrak{M}_{g,|\varsigma|}(B,[B])}$ are given by $H^{0}\left(f^{*} T_{\mathcal{X} / B}\right)$ and $H^{1}\left(f^{*} T_{\mathcal{X} / B}\right)$ respectively.

Under certain conditions the objects in the derived category defined by Equation (3.4) are represented by sheaves.

Proposition 3.1. Consider a log section $[f] \in \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)(S)$ where $S$ is a geometric point with the trivial log structure (whose image is thus necessarily a section of $\pi: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow B$ ). Let $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}$ be the collection of non-contact markings and let $\bar{f}: \bar{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ be log map associated to $f$ by removing markings in $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}$, see $\S 2.3$. We further assume that char $\mathbf{k}$ does not divide any of the non-zero contact orders of $f$. Then

(1) $\bar{f}$ is a log immersion.
(2) $N_{f} \cong N_{\bar{f}} \oplus \bigoplus_{k \in P} N_{p_{k} / \underline{C}}$ and $N_{h} \cong \oplus_{k=1}^{|\mathrm{c}|} N_{p_{k} / \underline{C}}$ are sheaves, where $\left\{p_{1}, \cdots, p_{|\mathrm{c}|}\right\}$ is the set of all markings and $N_{p_{i} / C} \cong \mathcal{O}_{p_{i}}$ is the normal bundle of the underlying marking.
(3) Further suppose that $f(C)$ is contained in the locus where $\pi: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow B$ is log smooth (where $B$ is equipped with the trivial log structure). Then we have an exact sequence

$$
0 \longrightarrow f^{*} T_{\mathcal{X} / B} \longrightarrow N_{f} \longrightarrow N_{h}=\oplus_{i=1}^{|\mathrm{c}|} N_{p_{i} / C} \longrightarrow 0
$$

where $N_{p_{i} / C} \cong \mathcal{O}_{p_{i}}$ is the normal bundle of the underlying marking.
Proof. Noting that the underlying morphism of $f$ is a closed embedding, (1) follows from Definition 2.5. (2) is a consequence of Corollary 2.7.
(3) We have the following commutative diagram
![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Since we are assuming $C$ is contained in the log smooth locus of $\pi$, the map $f^{*} T_{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow T_{B}$ is surjective. The kernel-cokernel sequence shows that the rightmost arrow is also surjective and has kernel isomorphic to $T_{\mathcal{X} / B}$.
3.3. Log sections through given points. Consider a finite set of points

$$
\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P} \subset \mathcal{X}^{\circ}=\mathcal{X} \backslash \operatorname{Supp}(\Delta)
$$

such that their images $p_{k}=\pi\left(q_{k}\right)$ are distinct. Denote by

$$
\operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right) \subset \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)
$$

the moduli of log sections with a specified subset of additional markings with images $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}$ in $B$. By a mild abuse of notation, we will use $p_{k}$ to denote the corresponding marking of the domain curve $C$ (as well as its image in $B$ ). Denote by

$$
\operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right) \subset \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)
$$

the closed substack parametrizing log sections such that the image of the marking $p_{k}$ is $q_{k}$ for all $k$. This is the moduli space of log sections through $\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P} \subset \mathcal{X}$. Denote by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)^{+} \subset \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right\}) \\
& \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)^{+} \subset \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$
