the open and closed substacks such that the markings with zero contact orders are exactly $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}$.

Let $[f] \in \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)^{+}(S)$ be a log section over a geometric log point $S$ with the trivial log structure, and $\bar{f}: \bar{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ be log map associated to $f$ by removing markings in $\left\{p_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}$. As in (2.7), we define the twisted normal complex:

$$
N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}:=N_{f}\left(-\sum_{k \in P} q_{k}\right)
$$

The cohomology groups $H^{0}\left(N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right)$ and $H^{1}\left(N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right)$ control the first-order infinitesimal deformations and obstructions of $[f]$ inside of $\operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)$ relative to Log, see $\S 2.4$.

Further assuming that char $\mathbf{k}$ does not divide any of the non-zero contact orders of $f$, then $N_{f}$ and $N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}$ are vector bundles by Proposition 3.1.

Lemma 3.2. Fix points $\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P} \subset \mathcal{X}^{\circ}$ with distinct images $p_{k}=\pi\left(q_{k}\right)$ in $B$.
Suppose that $M$ is an irreducible substack of $\operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)^{+}$parametrizing a separable dominant family of log sections such that all of the non-zero contact orders are not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$. Then for a general member $[f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}] \in M($ Spec $\mathbf{k})$, the vector bundle $N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}$ is generically globally generated.

Conversely, suppose we fix a log section $f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ through $\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}$ such that $N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}$ is generically globally generated and $H^{1}\left(C, N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right)=0$. Then there is a unique irreducible component $M \subset \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }\left(\mathcal{X} / B,\left\{q_{k}\right\}_{k \in P}\right)^{+}$containing $[f]$. Furthermore $M$ parametrizes a separable dominant family of log sections.

Proof. We first prove the first statement. Let $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow M$ be the universal family with the evaluation map $e v: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$. For a point $(f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}, p) \in \mathcal{U}$ with $p \in C$ non-marked, the tangent space is given by $T M_{f} \oplus T_{C} \mid p$. Since $e v$ is dominant and separable, for a general choice of $f$ and $p$ we have a surjection

$$
T M_{f} \oplus T_{C} \left.\right|_{p} \subset H^{0}\left(C, N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right) \oplus T_{C} \|_{p} \rightarrow f^{*} T_{\mathcal{X}} \|_{p}
$$

This implies that

$$
H^{0}\left(C, N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right) \rightarrow N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}} \|_{p}
$$

is surjective. Thus $N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}$ is generically globally generated.
Next we prove the second statement; the proof is almost backward. For a general nonmarked point $p \in C$,

$$
H^{0}\left(C, N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right) \rightarrow N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}} \|_{p}
$$

is surjective proving that

$$
H^{0}\left(C, N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right) \oplus T_{C} \|_{p} \rightarrow f^{*} T_{\mathcal{X}} \|_{p}
$$

is surjective. Furthermore, $H^{1}\left(C, N_{f,\left\{q_{k}\right\}}\right)=0$ implies that $\mathcal{U}$ is smooth around the point $p$. Thus $e v: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ is dominant and separable, proving the claim.

# 4. Free log curves 

A key tool for understanding rational curves on projective varieties is the notion of a (very) free curve. The study of free curves is closely tied to the geometric notions of uniruledness and rational connectedness. In this section we quickly describe the analogous theory in the $\log$ setting. Similar proposals have been put forward by e.g. [KM99, Cam11a, Cam10, CZ15, CZ19, CZ18].
4.1. Uniruledness and connectedness by rational log curves. We introduce the notation of (separable) uniruledness and rational connectedness of $X$ by log curves.

Definition 4.1. Let $X$ be a log smooth variety with strict normal crossings boundary and let $\varsigma$ be a collection of non-zero contact orders.
(1) We say $X$ is (separably) $\varsigma$-uniruled if there is a family of genus zero non-degenerate stable $\log$ maps $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow W$, ev: $\mathcal{U} \rightarrow X$ with contact orders $\varsigma$ such that $\underline{\mathcal{U}}=W \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$, $\operatorname{dim} W=\operatorname{dim} X-1$, and $e v$ is dominant (and separable).

(2) We say $X$ is (separably) $\varsigma$-rationally connected if there is a family of genus zero nondegenerate stable $\log$ maps $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow W, e v: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X$ with contact orders $\varsigma$ such that $\underline{\mathcal{U}}=W \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ and $e v^{(2)}: \mathcal{U} \times_{W} \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X^{2}$ is dominant (and separable).
Definition 4.2. Notations as in Definition 4.1, let $f: C \rightarrow X$ be a non-degenerate rational log curve over a geometric point with contact orders $\varsigma$. We say that $f$ is $\varsigma$-free (resp. $\varsigma$-very free) if $H^{1}\left(N_{f}(-1)\right)=0$ (resp. $H^{1}\left(N_{f}(-2)\right)=0$ ).
Corollary 4.3. Let $f: C \rightarrow X$ be a non-degenerate rational log curve over a geometric point with contact orders $\varsigma$. If $f^{*} T_{X}$ is nef (resp. ample), then $f$ is free (resp. very free).
Proof. To show that $f$ is $\varsigma$-free (resp. $\varsigma$-very free), one may first apply $\otimes \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{1}}(-1)$ (resp. $\otimes \mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{1}}(-2))$ to (2.5) and then take the corresponding long exact sequence. The statement then follows from Definition 4.2.
Proposition 4.4. Let $X$ be a log smooth variety with strict normal crossings boundary and let $\varsigma$ be a collection of non-zero contact orders not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$. Then $X$ is separably $\varsigma$-uniruled (resp. separably $\varsigma$-rationally connected) iff it admits a $\varsigma$-free (resp. $\varsigma$-very free) rational log curve.

We postpone the proof to Section 4.3.
4.2. Relatively free $\log$ sections. Recall that $B$ is of genus $g$. The above definition suggests the following notions of freeness for $\log$ sections:
Definition 4.5. Let $f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ be a $\log$ section with only contact markings. Assume that every contact order is not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$. It is called relatively generically free if $H^{1}\left(C, N_{f}\right)=0$ and $N_{f}$ is generically globally generated. If furthermore $N_{f}$ is globally generated, it is called relatively free. Note that it follows from Proposition 3.1 that the normal complex $N_{f}$ is actually a sheaf on $C$.

We call such an $f$ relatively $H N$-free (resp. relatively HN-very free) if $\mu^{\min }\left(N_{f}\right) \geq 2 g$ (resp. $\left.\mu^{\min }\left(N_{f}\right) \geq 2 g+1\right)$ where $\mu^{\min }(\mathcal{F})$ is the minimal slope of a torsion free sheaf $\mathcal{F}$.
Lemma 4.6. Let $f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ be a log section. Then we have the following implications:
$f$ is relatively $H N$-free $\Longrightarrow f$ is relatively free $\Longrightarrow f$ is relatively generically free.
In case $g=0$, the three notions of freeness are all equivalent. Thus, we say $f$ is relatively free if one of the three equivalent conditions is satisfied. Furthermore, when $g=0$ we say $f$ is relatively very free if it is relatively $H N$-very free.
Proof. The second implication is trivial. The first implication follows from Riemann-Roch and Serre duality. More precisely, it is an immediate consequence of [LRT25, Corollary 2.8]; the cited paper works over $\mathbb{C}$ but this argument is valid in arbitrary characteristic.
Lemma 4.7. Let $f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ be a log section with only contact markings and assume that all of the contact orders of $f$ are not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$. Let $M \subset \operatorname{Sec}_{\log }(\mathcal{X} / B)$ be a component containing $f$.
(1) Suppose that $f$ is relatively $H N$-free and let $b=\mu^{\min }\left(N_{f}\right)$. Then deformations of $C$ parametrized by $M$ go through $\lfloor b\rfloor-2 g+1$ general points;
(2) Conversely suppose that our ground field has characteristic 0 and deformations of $f$ parametrized by $M$ go through $2 g+1$ general points. Then a general deformation of $f$ in $M$ is relatively $H N$-free.

Proof. (1) Let $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{m}$ be general points on $B$. Then as long as $m \leq\lfloor b\rfloor-2 g$, the vector bundle $N_{f}\left(-p_{1}-\cdots-p_{m}\right)$ is globally generated with vanishing $H^{1}$ by [LRT25, Corollary 2.8]. Thus our assertion follows from Lemma 3.2.
(2) We fix a deformation $f^{\prime}: C^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ of $f$ going through a set of $2 g(B)$ general points on $\mathcal{X}$. Let $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{2 g}$ be the corresponding points on $C^{\prime}$. Then it follows from Lemma 3.2 that $N_{f^{\prime}}\left(-p_{1}-\cdots-p_{2 g}\right)$ is generically globally generated. [LRT25, Lemma 2.6] shows that $\mu^{\min }\left(N_{f^{\prime}}\left(-p_{1}-\cdots-p_{2 g}\right)\right) \geq 0$. Thus it follows that $\mu^{\min }\left(N_{f^{\prime}}\right) \geq 2 g$.
4.3. (Very) free log curves via (very) free $\log$ sections. Next, we relate the notions of free log curves and log sections in Definitions 4.2 and 4.5.

Given a non-degenerate stable $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$ with contact orders $\varsigma$ over a geometric point $S$, it naturally induces a $\log$ section of a trivial family:
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)
where $u$ is the morphism forgetting the log structure. We say the induced log section is non-trivial if the composition $C \xrightarrow{\rho} X \times \underline{C} \xrightarrow{\pi} X$ is not a contraction of the curve. Note that $\rho_{f}$ is non-trivial iff the image $f(C)$ is not a point. In particular $\rho_{f}$ is non-trivial if $\varsigma$ is not entirely zero.
Lemma 4.8. Notation as above. Suppose $C$ is rational and $\varsigma$ consists of non-zero contact orders which are not divisible by chark. Then $f$ is free (resp. very free) iff $\rho_{f}$ is relatively $H N$-free (resp. relatively $H N$-very free).
Proof. Consider the following commutative diagram
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

This provides a distinct triangle

$$
T_{\underline{C}} \longrightarrow N_{\rho_{f}} \longrightarrow N_{f} \xrightarrow{[1]} T_{\underline{C}}[1]
$$

Since $\underline{C} \cong \mathbb{P}^{1}$, by applying $\otimes \mathcal{O}_{\underline{C}}(-m)$ to the above distinct triangle for $m=1,2$ and taking the associated long exact sequence, we obtain an exact sequence

$$
0 \longrightarrow H^{1}\left(N_{\rho_{f}}(-m)\right) \underset{\longrightarrow}{\longrightarrow} H^{1}\left(N_{f}(-m)\right) \longrightarrow 0
$$

Suppose $f$ is free (resp. very free), i.e. $H^{1}\left(N_{f}(-1)\right)=0$ (resp. $H^{1}\left(N_{f}(-2)\right)=0$ ) by Definition 4.2. By the above exact sequence, this is equivalent to $H^{1}\left(N_{\rho_{f}}(-1)\right)=0$ (resp. $\left.H^{1}\left(N_{\rho_{f}}(-2)\right)=0\right)$. Since $C$ is a rational curve, this is equivalent to assuming that $\rho_{f}$ is relatively HN-free (resp. relatively HN-very free) as in Definition 4.5. This concludes the proof.

Lemma 4.9. Let $X$ be a log smooth projective variety with strict normal crossings boundary, and let $\pi: X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ be the trivial log fibration. Suppose $\varsigma$ consists of non-zero contact orders not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$. Then we have
(1) $X$ is separably $\varsigma$-uniruled if and only if the log fibration $\pi$ admits a non-trivial, free log section with contact orders $\varsigma$;
(2) $X$ is separably $\varsigma$-rationally connected if and only if the log fibration $\pi$ admits a very free log section with contact orders $\varsigma$.

Proof. (1) Suppose that $X$ is separably $\varsigma$-uniruled. Then there is a family $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow W$ of log rational curves with contact orders $\varsigma$ such that $\underline{\mathcal{U}}=W \times \mathbb{P}^{1}, \operatorname{dim} W=\operatorname{dim} X-1$, and the evaluation map $s: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X$ is dominant and separable. Let $\phi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ be the projection. We thus obtain a family of non-trivial log sections over $W$ :
![img-10.jpeg](img-10.jpeg)

While this family is not dominant (since $\operatorname{dim}(\mathcal{U})<\operatorname{dim}(X)+1$ ) we may select a torus action to sweep out the total space as follows. Fix two distinct points $x_{1}, x_{2} \in \mathbb{P}^{1}$ and an identification $\mathbb{P}^{1} \backslash\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}\right\} \cong \mathbb{G}_{m}$ with a torus. This defines a multiplication morphism

$$
\mathbf{m}: \mathbb{G}_{m} \times \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}
$$

with two fixed points $\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}\right\}$. This $\mathbf{m}$ is a separable and dominant morphism. Now we extend (4.1) to the following commutative diagram
![img-11.jpeg](img-11.jpeg)

The composition of the upper arrows gives a family of non-trivial log sections

$$
\widetilde{e v}: \widetilde{\mathcal{U}}:=\mathbb{G}_{m} \times \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}
$$

over $\widetilde{W}:=\mathbb{G}_{m} \times W$. Note that $\widetilde{e v}$ is separable and dominant. Let $f: C \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ be a general log section parametrized by $\widetilde{W}$. Lemma 3.2 implies that $N_{f}$ is generically globally generated. Since the underlying curve is a smooth rational curve, we conclude that $f$ is free.

Conversely, suppose that there is a free $\log$ section $f: C \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ with contact orders $\varsigma$. Let $M$ be the irreducible component of $\operatorname{Sec}_{\varsigma}\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} / \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)$ containing $f$. Let $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow M$ be the universal family over $M$ with the evaluation map $e v: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$. Lemma 3.2 implies that the evaluation map $e v: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ is dominant and separable. Moreover since it parametrizes sections, we have $\underline{\mathcal{U}}=M \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$. Then the composition $\mathcal{U} \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow X$

with the projection is also dominant and separable. In particular, it is smooth at a general unmarked point $(x, y) \in \underline{\mathcal{U}}=M \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ so that we have a surjection of tangents

$$
T_{M, x} \oplus T_{\mathbb{P}^{1}, y} \longrightarrow T_{X, e v(x, y)}
$$

whose kernel does not contain $T_{\mathbb{P}^{1}, y}$. We may choose a general complete intersection $W \subset M$ through $x$ of dimension $\operatorname{dim} X-1$. Then

$$
T_{W, x} \oplus T_{\mathbb{P}^{1}, y} \subset T_{M, x} \oplus T_{\mathbb{P}^{1}, y} \longrightarrow T_{X, e v(x, y)}
$$

is still surjective so that the composition $\mathcal{C}_{W} \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow X$ is separable and dominant. Thus our assertion follows.
(2) Suppose that our $\log$ variety $(X, \Delta)$ is separably $\varsigma$-rationally connected. This will imply that there is a family $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow W$ of $\log$ rational curves with contact orders $\varsigma$ and evaluation map $s: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X$ such that $\underline{\mathcal{U}}=W \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ and the evaluation map $e v^{(2)}: \mathcal{U} \times_{W} \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X^{2}$ is dominant and separable. We use a similar construction in (1) but instead of using $\mathbb{G}_{m}$ we use the 2-dimensional affine group $\mathbb{G}_{a} \rtimes \mathbb{G}_{m}$. Thus we construct $\widetilde{\mathcal{U}} \rightarrow \widetilde{W}=\left(\mathbb{G}_{a} \rtimes \mathbb{G}_{m}\right) \times W$ with the evaluation map $\widetilde{s}: \widetilde{\mathcal{U}} \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ using multiplication by a $\mathbb{G}_{a} \rtimes \mathbb{G}_{m}$-action on $\mathbb{P}^{1}$. Then $\widetilde{e v}^{(2)}: \widetilde{\mathcal{U}} \times_{\widetilde{W}} \widetilde{\mathcal{U}} \rightarrow\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)^{2}$ is dominant and separable. This will imply that there is a component $M$ of $\operatorname{Sec}_{\varsigma}\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} / \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)$ with universal family $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow M$ such that $e v^{(2)}: \mathcal{U} \times_{M} \mathcal{U} \rightarrow\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)^{2}$ is dominant and separable. Then it follows from Lemma 3.2 that a general $f: C \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ parametrized by $M$ is very free.

Conversely suppose that there is a very free $\log$ section $f: C \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ with contact orders $\varsigma$. Let $M$ be a component of $\operatorname{Sec}_{\varsigma}\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} / \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)$ containing $f$. Let $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow M$ be the universal family over $M$ with the evaluation map $e v: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$. Then since $N_{f}$ is ample, for any points $p, q$ on $C, H^{0}\left(C, N_{f}\right) \rightarrow N_{f} \left.\right|_{p} \oplus N_{f} \mid q$ is surjective. This means that for general $p, q$, we have a surjection $H^{0}\left(C, N_{f}\right) \oplus T_{C} \left.\right|_{p} \oplus T_{C} \left.\right|_{q} \rightarrow f^{*} T_{X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}} \mid p \oplus f^{*} T_{X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}} \mid q$. We conclude that the evaluation map $e v^{(2)}: \mathcal{U} \times_{M} \mathcal{U} \rightarrow\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)^{2}$ is dominant and separable proving the claim.

Proof of Proposition 4.4. This follows directly from Lemmas 4.8 and 4.9.

# 5. CAMPana MAPS and CURVES 

Here we recall the definitions of Campana curves and Campana sections. First let us define Campana orbifolds and Campana fibrations:

Definition 5.1. Let $\underline{X}$ be a smooth projective variety and $\Delta=\sum_{i} \Delta_{i}$ be a strict normal crossings divisor on $\underline{X}$ such that $\Delta_{i}$ is irreducible. Let $X$ be the log scheme associated to the pair $(\underline{X}, \Delta)$. For each $i$ let $m_{i}$ be either a positive integer $\geq 1$ or $\infty$ and set $\epsilon_{i}=1-\frac{1}{m_{i}}$. We define

$$
\Delta_{\epsilon}=\sum_{i}\left(1-\frac{1}{m_{i}}\right) \Delta_{i}
$$

and call the pair $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ a Campana orbifold. We say $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is a klt Campana pair if all $m_{i}$ are positive integers. This is equivalent to saying that the pair $\left(\underline{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ has only klt singularities.

A Campana fibration over $B$ is a Campana orbifold $\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ with a $\log$ fibration $\pi$ : $(\mathcal{X}, \Delta) \rightarrow B$. Similarly we say $\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) / B$ is a klt Campana fibration if all the $m_{i}$ are positive integers.

Next we define the notion of Campana maps:
Definition 5.2. Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a Campana orbifold. Suppose $\varsigma$ is a collection of positive contact orders as in (2.1) for stable log maps to $X$. As before we will let $c_{k, i}$ denote the multiplicity of the $i$ th irreducible component $\Delta_{\epsilon}$ along the $k$ th marked point.

We say that $\varsigma$ is of Campana type if for every irreducible component $\Delta_{\epsilon}$ of $\Delta$ :
(1) when $m_{i}<\infty$, every index $k$ satisfies either $c_{k, i}=0$ or $c_{k, i} \geq m_{i}$.
(2) when $m_{i}=\infty$, there is at most one index $k$ with $c_{k, i}>0$.

A stable $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow X$ over a $\log$ point $S$ is called a Campana map if the collection of its contact orders are of Campana type. We call $f$ a Campana curve if $f$ is non-degenerate, or equivalently $\mathcal{M}_{S}$ is trivial. Recall that if $f$ is non-degenerate, then $C$ is smooth and $f^{-1}(\Delta)$ consists of only marked points.

Next let $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ be a Campana fibration over a smooth projective curve $B$ of genus $g$. A genus $g$ stable $\log$ map $f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ over a geometric $\log$ point $S$ is called a stable Campana map of section type if $f$ is a Campana map to $\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$, and the composition $C \rightarrow \mathcal{X} \rightarrow B$ has degree 1. When $C$ is a Campana curve, we call $f$ a Campana section.

The condition (2) means that when $m_{i}=\infty$ and $f\left(p_{k}\right) \in \Delta_{i}$, then $f\left(C \backslash\left\{p_{k}\right\}\right) \cap \Delta_{i}=\emptyset$. In particular, when every multiplicity is $\infty$ then the $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-curves in $X$ studied in [CZ19] are examples of Campana curves.
Remark 5.3. In Definition 5.2, the condition on contact orders when $m_{i}=\infty$ is slightly different than the typical definition used by arithmetic geometers. The exactly analogous definition is to fix a finite set $S$ of places on $B$ and to insist that the intersections of $\Delta_{\epsilon}$ and $f(C)$ can only happen above these finitely many points. Our definition allows for more flexibility.
Remark 5.4. An alternative method for dealing with infinite contact orders in Definition 5.2 would be to insist that our curve meets $\cup_{\left\{{ }_{i}=\infty} \Delta_{\epsilon}\right.}$ at only one point. This would be more closely analogous to the notion of an $\mathbb{A}^{1}$-curve. It has the additional advantage that if we construct $\Delta_{\epsilon}^{\prime}$ from $\Delta_{\epsilon}$ by reducing the multiplicities then a Campana curve for $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ can be transformed into a Campana curve for $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}^{\prime}\right)$ by taking a finite cover ramified at the point of intersection with the multiplicity $\infty$ divisors. On the other hand, this alternative definition is not as flexible as Definition 5.2.
Remark 5.5. Suppose that $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is a Campana orbifold and that $\phi: X^{\prime} \rightarrow X$ is a birational morphism. It is natural to equip $X^{\prime}$ with a Campana orbifold structure $\left(X^{\prime}, \Delta_{\epsilon}^{\prime}\right)$ in a "minimal" way (see [PSTVA21, Section 3.6]). However, with this choice the strict transform of a Campana curve on $X$ need not be a Campana curve on $X^{\prime}$. In fact, there does not seem to be a natural way of defining a "birationally invariant" theory of Campana curves.

Next suppose that $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ is a Campana fibration. The previous paragraph shows that the set of Campana sections can really depend on the integral model $\mathcal{X}$ and not just on the generic fiber $\mathcal{X}_{K(B)}$. For this reason we will always specify the integral model $(\mathcal{X}, \Delta)$ when discussing Campana sections.
5.1. Campana uniruledness and Campana rational connectedness. Here we introduce the notation of (separable) Campana uniruledness and (separable) Campana rational connectedness:

Definition 5.6. Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a Campana orbifold.
(1) We say $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is (separably) Campana uniruled if there exist a collection of contact orders $\varsigma$ of Campana type such that $X$ is (separably) $\varsigma$-uniruled. Furthermore, when all non-zero contact orders of $\varsigma$ are not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$, we say $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is (separably) Campana uniruled by good contact orders.
(2) We say $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is (separably) Campana rationally connected if there exist a collection of contact orders $\varsigma$ of Campana type such that $X$ is (separably) $\varsigma$-rationally connected. We also define (separably) Campana rational connectedness by good contact orders in an analogous way.

Lemma 5.7. Let $(X, \Delta)$ be a Campana orbifold.
(1) A Campana orbifold $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is separably Campana uniruled by good contact orders if and only if there is a non-trivial free Campana section of contact orders $\varsigma$ on $\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} / \mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon} \times \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)$ such that every non-zero contact order of $\varsigma$ is not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$;
(2) a Campana orbifold $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is separably Campana rationally connected by good contact orders if and only if there is a very free Campana section of contact orders $\varsigma$ on $\left(X \times \mathbb{P}^{1} / \mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon} \times \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)$ such that every non-zero contact order of $\varsigma$ is not divisible by char $\mathbf{k}$.

Proof. This follows from Lemma 4.9.
An important conjecture in this direction, due to Campana, is:
Conjecture 5.8 (Campana). Assume that our ground field has characteristic 0 . Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Fano orbifold, i.e., $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is a klt Campana orbifold such that $-\left(K_{\underline{X}}+\Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is ample. Then $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is Campana rationally connected.

For our applications, we will need the following conjecture.
Definition 5.9. Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Campana orbifold. We say that $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is strongly Campana uniruled if there exists a free Campana curve $f: C \rightarrow X$ such that the class $f_{*}[C]$ is in the interior of the nef cone $\operatorname{Nef}_{1}(X)$ of curves.

Conjecture 5.10. Assume that our ground field has characteristic 0 . Then every klt Fano orbifold $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is strongly Campana uniruled.

Note that when $X$ has Picard rank 1, being in the interior of the nef cone is automatic.
Proposition 5.11. Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Fano orbifold. Assume that Conjecture 5.10 holds. Then for each $\Delta_{i}$, there exists a free Campana curve $f: C \rightarrow X$ such that $f(C)$ meets with the codimension 1 stratum of $\Delta_{i}$.

Proof. This follows from Proposition 2.11 and Conjecture 5.10. Indeed, one can split contact orders inductively as described in Section 2.8. While doing so, freeness will be preserved by Remark 2.12.

# 6. WEAK APPROXIMATION 

Weak approximation for Campana sections looks somewhat different than weak approximation for sections. Indeed, by Remark 5.5 the notion of a Campana section depends on the choice of integral model $\pi:(\mathcal{X}, \Delta) \rightarrow B$ and not just the generic fiber.

6.1. Setting up weak approximation for Campana pairs. Let $B$ be a smooth projective curve over an algebraically closed field. Suppose that $\left(\mathcal{X}_{q}, \Delta_{q}\right)$ is a smooth projective geometrically integral klt Campana pair over the function field $K$ of $B$. For any place $b$ of $K$, we denote by $\widehat{\mathcal{O}}_{B, b}$ the completion of the local ring $\mathcal{O}_{B, b}$ with respect to the maximal ideal and by $K_{b}$ the fraction field of $\widehat{\mathcal{O}}_{B, b}$.
Definition 6.1. Let $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ be a klt Campana fibration. We say that $b \in B$ is a place of good reduction if there exists a regular model $\pi^{\prime}: \underline{\mathcal{X}}^{\prime} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec} \mathcal{O}_{B, b}$ of the generic fiber $\underline{\mathcal{X}}_{q}$ such that the special fiber $\underline{\mathcal{X}}_{p}^{\prime}$ is smooth.

Note that this definition is the same as the usual one and does not rely on the log structure in any way.
Definition 6.2. Let $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ be a klt Campana fibration. Let $\operatorname{Spec} \mathbf{k}[t] /\left(t^{n+1}\right)$ be the $n$-th jet scheme. We say an $n$-th jet $\sigma: \operatorname{Spec} \mathbf{k}[t] /\left(t^{n+1}\right) \rightarrow \underline{\mathcal{X}}$ is an admissible $n$-th jet if the composition

$$
\operatorname{Spec} \mathbf{k}[t] /\left(t^{n+1}\right) \rightarrow \underline{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow B
$$

is a closed embedding.
Let $I_{\sigma}$ denote the set of indices $i$ such that $\sigma(\operatorname{Spec} \mathbf{k}) \subset \Delta_{i}$. We say an admissible $n$-th jet $\sigma$ is a Campana $n$-th jet if it satisfies:
(1) $n \geq \max _{i}\left\{m_{i}\right\}_{i \in I_{\sigma}}$, and
(2) for $i \in I_{\sigma}$ the ideal defined by the pullback of $\Delta_{i}$ is given by $\left(t^{m}\right)$ with $m \geq m_{i}$.

We say a Campana fibration $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ satisfies weak approximation if for any finite number of Campana jets sitting in distinct fibers, there is a Campana section $f: C \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ which induces the given Campana jets. Similarly, we say that $\pi$ satisfies weak approximation at places of good reduction if any finite number of Campana jets sitting in distinct fibers of good reduction are induced by a Campana section.
6.2. Deformation theory of log sections while fixing jets. In Section 2.4 we discussed the deformation theory of log sections through fixed points. In this section we extend these results to discuss sections through fixed jets. The strategy is the usual one (e.g., [HT06, Section 2.3]): we blow-up to translate jet data into incidence data.

Suppose that $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ is a klt Campana fibration. Let $\left\{\left(p_{j}, \sigma_{j}\right)\right\}$ be a finite set of admissible jets living in distinct fibers. We assume that these jets are not supported on the boundary $\Delta$. Suppose that the jet $\sigma_{j}$ lies over the point $b_{j} \in B$. Let $\widehat{B}_{b}$ denote the completion of $B$ at $b$ and let $\widehat{\pi}: \widehat{\mathcal{X}}_{b} \rightarrow \widehat{B}_{b}$ denote the base-change of $\pi$. By Hensel's Lemma, each $\sigma_{j}$ is induced by a jet $\widehat{\sigma}_{j}$ over $\widehat{B}_{b_{j}}$.

We then replace $\mathcal{X}$ with the following birational modification. For each jet $\sigma_{j}$, we repeatedly perform point blow-ups in the fiber over $b_{j}$ where at each step we blow-up the point defined by the strict transform of $\widehat{\sigma}_{j}$. The result will be a smooth birational model $\mathcal{X}^{\prime}$ of $\mathcal{X}$ equipped with a morphism $\pi^{\prime}: \mathcal{X}^{\prime} \rightarrow B$ with the following property: for each $j$, there is a distinguished irreducible component $E_{j}$ of the fiber over $b_{j}$ such that a section $C$ of $\pi$ will be tangent to $\sigma_{j}$ if and only if the strict transform of $C$ meets $E_{j}$. We say that $\phi: \mathcal{X}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ extracts the jets $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}$. For an $n$-th admissible jet, one can construct such a $\mathcal{X}^{\prime}$ by blowing up $n+1$ times.
Lemma 6.3. Let $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ be a klt Campana fibration. Suppose $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{r}$ is a finite set of admissible jets supported on distinct fibers such that the support of jets does not lie on

$\Delta$. Let $\phi: \mathcal{X}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}$ be the birational model extracting the jets $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}$. Suppose that $C$ is a log section of $\pi$ with the canonical log structure that approximates the jets $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}$ and let $C^{\prime}$ be its strict transform on $\mathcal{X}^{\prime}$. Then

$$
N_{C^{\prime} / \mathcal{X}^{\prime}} \cong N_{C / \mathcal{X}}\left(-\sum n_{j} p_{j}\right)
$$

In particular the deformation theory of sections $C$ of $\pi$ approximating $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{r}$ is given by the twisted normal bundle in the equation above.

Proof. Recall that $\phi$ is a composition of blow-ups at smooth points. Arguing inductively, it suffices to compute what happens when $\phi$ is the blow-up of a single point $p$ not contained in $\Delta$. Letting $i: E \rightarrow \mathcal{X}^{\prime}$ denote the inclusion of the exceptional divisor with the trivial log structure, we have an exact diagram of sheaves
![img-12.jpeg](img-12.jpeg)
where $\mathcal{K}$ is the cokernel of $N_{C^{\prime} / \mathcal{X}^{\prime}} \rightarrow N_{C / \mathcal{X}}$. We conclude that $N_{C^{\prime} / \mathcal{X}^{\prime}} \cong N_{C / \mathcal{X}}(-p)$ as desired.
6.3. Weak approximation in characteristic 0 . Our goal in this section is to prove the following theorem:

Theorem 6.4. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 . Let $S$ be a finite set of closed points on $B$ and we assume that $\underline{\pi}: \underline{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow B$ satisfies weak approximation outside of $S$. Let $\pi:\left(\mathcal{X}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow B$ be a klt Campana fibration over $\mathbf{k}$ such that a general fiber of $\pi$ is rationally connected and is strongly Campana uniruled. Suppose we fix points $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{r} \in \mathcal{X}$ supported on distinct fibers outside of $S$ and for each index $j$ we choose a Campana $n_{j}$-th jet $\sigma_{j}$ at $p_{j}$. Then there exists a Campana section approximating the jet data $\left\{p_{j}, \sigma_{j}\right\}$.

We assume that $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{s}$ are contained in $\Delta$ and $p_{s+1}, \cdots, p_{r}$ are not contained in $\Delta$. First we prepare the following lemma:

Lemma 6.5. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 . Let $S$ be a finite set of closed points on $B$ and we assume that $\underline{\pi}: \underline{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow B$ satisfies weak approximation outside of $S$. Let $\underline{\pi}: \underline{\mathcal{X}} \rightarrow B$ be a flat projective morphism from a smooth projective variety such that a general fiber is rationally connected and let $\rho \geq 0$ be any non-negative real number. For $j=1, \cdots, r$, let $\left\{p_{j}, \sigma_{j}\right\}$ be an admissible $n_{j}$-th jet such that $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{r} \in \underline{\mathcal{X}}$

are sitting in fibers outside of $S$. Then $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}$ can be approximated by a section $f: \underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ of $\underline{\pi}$ such that

$$
\mu^{\min }\left(N_{\underline{C} / \underline{X}}\left(-\sum_{j} n_{j} p_{j}\right)\right) \geq \rho+2 g(B)
$$

Proof. First let us assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is uncountable. We fix $\ell=\lceil\rho\rceil+2 g(B)+1$ very general points $q_{1}, \cdots, q_{\ell}$. By our assumption, we can find a section $\underline{f}^{\prime}: \underline{C}^{\prime} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ that approximates our finite number of jets $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}$ and also goes through our $\ell$ very general points. Let $M$ be the irreducible component of the moduli space parametrizing sections which approximate our jets $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}$ such that $\underline{f}^{\prime} \in M$. Since our points are very general, a general section $\underline{C}$ parametrized by $M$ goes through $\ell$ very general points. This implies that $N_{\underline{C} / \underline{X}}\left(-\sum_{j} n_{j} p_{j}-\sum_{k=1}^{\ell-1} q_{k}\right)$ is generically globally generated. Thus it follows from [LRT25, Lemma 2.6] that we have

$$
\mu^{\min }\left(N_{\underline{C} / \underline{X}}\left(-\sum_{j} n_{j} p_{j}\right)\right) \geq\lceil\rho\rceil+2 g(B)
$$

verifying our assertion.
When $\mathbf{k}$ is countable, we consider the moduli space $M$ of sections approximating the jet data $\left(p_{j}, \sigma_{j}\right)$. Let $\mathbf{k}^{\prime} \supset \mathbf{k}$ be an uncountable algebraically closed field. Then there exists an irreducible component $M_{1} \subset M$ such that $M_{1} \otimes \mathbf{k}^{\prime}$ contains an open subset $U$ parametrizing sections $\underline{C}$ such that

$$
\mu^{\min }\left(N_{\underline{C} / \underline{X}}\left(-\sum_{j} n_{j} p_{j}\right)\right) \geq\lceil\rho\rceil+2 g(B)
$$

Since $\mathbf{k}$-valued points on $M_{1}$ are Zariski dense, one can find a section $\underline{C}$ defined over $\mathbf{k}$ that satisfies

$$
\mu^{\min }\left(N_{\underline{C} / \underline{X}}\left(-\sum_{j} n_{j} p_{j}\right)\right) \geq\lceil\rho\rceil+2 g(B)
$$

Thus our assertion follows.
We also need another lemma:
Lemma 6.6. Let $\underline{\pi}: \underline{X} \rightarrow B$ be a flat projective morphism from a smooth projective variety with a boundary divisor $\Delta=\cup_{i} \Delta_{i}$ which is a SNC divisor and flat over $B$. For $j=1, \cdots, r$, let $\left\{p_{j}, \sigma_{j}\right\}$ be an admissible $n_{j}$-th jet such that each point $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{r} \in \underline{X}$ is a smooth point of the fiber containing it. Suppose that we have a section $C$ approximating these jets and not contained in the support of $\Delta$. Then there is a birational morphism $\beta: \underline{\bar{X}} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ from a smooth projective variety $\underline{\bar{X}}$ such that the strict transform $\widehat{\Delta}$ of $\Delta$ is $S N C, \beta$ is an isomorphism over $\underline{X} \backslash\left\{p_{1}, \cdots, p_{r}\right\}$, and the strict transform $\widehat{C}$ of $C$ does not meet with $\widehat{\Delta}$ over $\underline{\pi}\left(p_{j}\right)$ for any $j=1, \cdots, r$.

Proof. It is enough to prove the statement for one section $C$ and a point $p \in C$. If $p \notin \Delta$, then there is nothing to prove. Suppose that $p \in \Delta$. Then we successively blow up the support $p$ of the strict transform of a section $f: C \rightarrow \underline{X}$. Then the local intersection multiplicity of the strict transform $\widehat{C}$ and the strict transform $\widehat{\Delta}$ is strictly decreasing along successive blow-ups, so eventually it becomes 0 , proving the claim. Note that the smoothness of $p$ in

its fiber is also preserved due to the fact that it is the intersection of the fiber with a section. Also note that if the local intersection of $C$ and $\Delta_{i}$ is given by $k_{i}$, then we need to perform successive blow ups $\max \left\{k_{i}\right\}$-times.

Here is our strategy for proving Theorem 6.4. Suppose we fix a finite set of Campana jets supported on fibers of good reduction. By the assumption we can find a section $\underline{C}$ which induces this finite set of jets. Of course $\underline{C}$ might not satisfy the Campana condition at the other points of intersection $\left\{q_{k}\right\}$ with $\bar{\Delta}$. By gluing on $\pi$-vertical Campana curves and smoothing (while leaving the jets fixed), we increase the intersection numbers at the $q_{k}$ to achieve the Campana condition everywhere.

Proof of Theorem 6.4. Let $\underline{C}$ be a general section in $M$ obtained in the proof of Lemma 6.5 with $\rho=2 g$. If at a place $b=\pi(p)$ of a Campana $n$-th jet $(p, \sigma)$, the local intersection multiplicity of $C$ and $\Delta_{i}$ is greater than $n$ for some $i$, then we may replace $(p, \sigma)$ by a deeper jet of $C$ at $p$ so that the local intersection multiplicity of $C$ and $\Delta_{i}$ is smaller than $n$ for any $i$. Let $\beta: \underline{\tilde{X}} \rightarrow \underline{X}$ be a birational projective morphism constructed in Lemma 6.6. By taking the strict transform, we have a stable map $\underline{f}: \underline{C} \rightarrow \underline{\tilde{X}}$. Then note that $\underline{C}$ meets with the exceptional divisor of $\beta$ only over points $\pi\left(p_{j}\right)$. We impose the log structure on $\underline{\tilde{X}}$ associated to the pair $(\underline{\tilde{X}}, \bar{\Delta})$ where $\bar{\Delta}$ is the strict transform of $\Delta$. We can think of $\left(\tilde{\mathcal{X}}, \bar{\Delta}_{\epsilon}\right)$ as a Campana pair by equipping each irreducible component of $\bar{\Delta}$ with the same multiplicity as the corresponding component of $\Delta$. Then we impose the minimal log structure on $C \rightarrow S$ so that $f: C \rightarrow \tilde{\mathcal{X}}$ is a $\log$ section with only contact markings. Let $\left\{q_{k}\right\}$ denote the set of marked points on $C$. By construction $f\left(q_{k}\right)$ is a smooth point of $\bar{\Delta}$ and $f(C)$ meets with $\bar{\Delta}$ transversally at those points. Let $\ell$ be the number of $q_{k}$ 's where the Campana condition is not satisfied.

It follows from the proof of Lemma 4.7 that $f: C \rightarrow \tilde{\mathcal{X}}$ goes through $2 g+1$ general points while approximating the jet data $\left\{\left(\widetilde{p}_{j}, \widetilde{\sigma}_{j}\right)\right\}$ induced by $\left\{\left(p_{j}, \sigma_{j}\right)\right\}$. In particular, this implies that

$$
\mu^{\min }\left(N_{f}\left(-\sum_{j=1}^{r} \widetilde{n}_{j} \widetilde{p}_{j}\right)\right) \geq 2 g
$$

This means that $N_{f}\left(-\sum_{j=1}^{r} \widetilde{n}_{j} \widetilde{p}_{j}\right)$ has vanishing $H^{1}$ and is globally generated. Let $q_{k}$ be a marked point on $C$ which does not satisfy the Campana condition for $\left(\tilde{\mathcal{X}}, \bar{\Delta}_{\epsilon}\right)$. By the construction, $f\left(q_{k}\right)$ is a general point in a codimension 1 strata of a general fiber. By assumption this fiber possesses a free Campana rational curve which is in the interior of the nef cone. Proposition 5.11 implies that we have a free $\pi$-vertical Campana rational curve passing through $f\left(q_{k}\right)$. Then we glue $C$ and $T$ via a contracted component $L$ so that we obtain a glued stable $\log$ map $\widetilde{f}: \widetilde{C} \rightarrow \widetilde{\mathcal{X}}$ using the construction of Section 2.6. We claim that Proposition 2.10 allows us to smooth $\widetilde{f}: \widetilde{C} \rightarrow \widetilde{\mathcal{X}}$ while approximating the jet data $\left\{\widetilde{p}_{j}, \widetilde{\sigma}_{j}\right\}$. Indeed, the assumptions of Proposition 2.10 follow from Lemma 2.8 and Proposition 2.9. We denote its general smoothing as a $\log$ section $f_{1}: C_{1} \rightarrow \widetilde{\mathcal{X}}$. Then the number of marked points $q_{k}$ which does not satisfy Campana condition is $\ell-1$. Moreover since $f: C \rightarrow \widetilde{\mathcal{X}}$ goes through $2 g+1$ general points, $f_{1}: C_{1} \rightarrow \widetilde{\mathcal{X}}$ goes through $2 g+1$ general points as well. Thus by repeatedly applying the construction of Section 2.6 to marked points which do not satisfy the Campana condition and smoothing the resulting stable maps we

can construct a Campana log section $f_{\ell}: C_{\ell} \rightarrow \widetilde{\mathcal{X}}$ which approximates the jet data $\left\{\widetilde{p}_{j}, \widetilde{\sigma}_{j}\right\}$. Then $h: C_{\ell} \rightarrow \underline{\widetilde{\mathcal{X}}} \rightarrow \underline{\mathcal{X}}$ witnesses our assertion.
Proof of Theorem 1.6. This follows from Theorem 6.4.
Corollary 6.7. Assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 0 . Let $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Campana orbifold such that $\underline{X}$ is rationally connected and $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is strongly Campana uniruled. Then $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is Campana rationally connected.

Proof. First let us assume that $\mathbf{k}$ is uncountable. Let $\mathcal{X}=X \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$ and $\widetilde{\Delta}_{\epsilon}=\Delta_{\epsilon} \times \mathbb{P}^{1}$. We pick two very general points on $\mathcal{X}$. It follows from Theorem 6.4 that we can find a Campana section $C$ of $\left(\left(\mathcal{X}, \widetilde{\Delta}_{\epsilon}\right) / \mathbb{P}^{1}\right)$ passing through these two points. Since these two points are very general, $C$ log-deforms to go through two general points on $\mathcal{X}$. It follows from the proof of Lemma 4.7 that a general log-deformation of $C$ is very free. Thus our assertion follows. When $\mathbf{k}$ is countable, one can reduce to the statement for uncountable fields as in Lemma 6.5.

Proof of Corollary 1.7. This follows from Corollary 6.7.

# 7. CAMPana CURVES FOR $\mathbb{P}^{1}$-FIBRATIONS 

Suppose that $\left(\mathbb{P}_{q}^{1}, D_{q}\right)$ is a klt Fano orbifold with a smooth integral model $\pi: S \rightarrow B$. Explicitly, this means that:

- $S$ is smooth and comes equipped with a SNC divisor $\mathcal{D}$ that is flat and generically SNC over $B$.
- The general fiber of $\pi$ is isomorphic to $\mathbb{P}^{1}$.

The possible coefficient choices depend on the support of $\mathcal{D}$ :
(1) If $\mathcal{D}$ consists of a single section or degree 2 multisection, we can assign to it any integer $m \geq 2$.
(2) If $\mathcal{D}$ consists of two sections, we can assign to the pair any integers $m_{1}, m_{2} \geq 2$.
(3) If $\mathcal{D}$ consists of a single degree 3 multisection, we must assign it the multiplicity $m=2$.
(4) If $\mathcal{D}$ consists of a section $D_{1}$ and a degree 2 multisection $D_{2}$, we must assign them the multiplicities $\left(m_{1}, m_{2}\right)=(m, 2)$ or $(2,3)$ where $m \geq 2$ is any integer.
(5) If $D$ consists of three sections, then multiplicities are $\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3}\right)=(2,2, m),(2,3,3),(2,3,4)$ or $(2,3,5)$ where $m$ is any integer $m \geq 2$.
Our goal of this section is to show Conjecture 5.10 for $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, D\right)$ where $D=\left.\mathcal{D}\right|_{\mathbb{P}^{1}}$ for a general fiber of $\pi$.
7.1. The existence of free Campana rational curves in the absolute case. Assume that $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is a klt Fano orbifold. When we have two Campana orbifolds $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ and $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon}^{\prime}\right)$ such that $\Delta_{\epsilon} \geq \Delta_{\epsilon}^{\prime}$, then a Campana curve with respect to $\Delta_{\epsilon}$ is automatically a Campana curve with respect to $\Delta_{\epsilon}^{\prime}$. So we may assume that
(1) $\Delta$ consists of two points with $\left(m_{1}, m_{2}\right)=(m, m)$ where $m \geq 2$ is an integer;
(2) $\Delta$ consists of three points with $\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3}\right)=(2,2, m)$ where $m \geq 2$ is an integer, or;
(3) $\Delta$ consists of three points with $\left(m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3}\right)=(2,3,5)$.

Using this simplification we show:
Theorem 7.1. Let $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ be a klt Fano orbifold. Then there exists a stable log map $f: C \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ of genus 0 such that $f$ is a free Campana curve. Moreover, one can choose $f$ so that the log normal sheaf of $f$ has degree $m$ where $m$ is any non-negative integer.

Proof. We first assume that our ground field $\mathbf{k}$ has characteristic 0 . In the case (1), one can find a degree $m$ cover $f^{\prime}: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ totally ramified at the support of $\Delta$. If we equip the domain with the log structure associated to $f^{\prime-1}(\Delta)$ then $f^{\prime}$ is a Campana rational curve. It is also free since the log normal sheaf has degree 0 . Let $g: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ be a general degree $d$ cover and equip the domain with the log structure associated to $g^{-1} f^{\prime-1}(\Delta)$. Then $f=f^{\prime} \circ g$ is a Campana curve and the log normal sheaf has degree $2 d-2$. This achieves every nonnegative even degree for the log normal sheaf; for an odd degree, we can instead let $g$ be simple ramified at one point of $g^{-1} f^{\prime-1}(\Delta)$. Thus our assertion follows.

In the cases (2) and (3), we claim that there exists a cover $f^{\prime}: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ branched at the support of $\Delta$ with branch datum

$$
\left(m_{1}, \cdots, m_{1}\right),\left(m_{2}, \cdots, m_{2}\right),\left(m_{3}, \cdots, m_{3}\right)
$$

In fact, these are classical examples of Belyi maps obtained by taking quotients of $\mathbb{P}^{1}$ by finite subgroups of $\mathrm{PGL}_{2}(\mathbf{k})$. Case (2) corresponds to quotients by a dihedral group of order $2 m$ whose action has stabilizers of size $2,2, m$. This gives a degree $2 m$ map $f^{\prime}: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ with branch data $\left(2^{m}\right),\left(2^{m}\right),(m, m)$. Case (3) corresponds to a quotient by the icosahedral group whose action has stabilizers of size $2,3,5$. This gives a degree $60 \operatorname{map} f^{\prime}: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ with branch data $\left(2^{30}\right),\left(3^{20}\right),\left(5^{12}\right)$. It is clear that in each case $f^{\prime}$ defines a Campana curve and the degree of log normal sheaf is given by 0 . Let $g: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ be a general degree $d$ cover. Then $f=f^{\prime} \circ g$ is a Campana curve and the log normal sheaf has degree $2 d-2$. For odd degrees, we may let $g$ simply ramified at one of $g^{-1} f^{\prime \prime}(\Delta)$. Thus our assertion follows.

We next assume that our ground field $\mathbf{k}$ has characteristic $p$. In the case (1), we can use the same argument after perhaps increasing the degree of the cover to ensure that it is coprime to $m$. In the cases (2) and (3), we can again look for a cover $f^{\prime}: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ constructed by taking a quotient by a finite subgroup of $\mathrm{PGL}_{2}(\mathbf{k})$. The classification of such subgroups is presented in [Fab23, Theorem B, Theorem C, Remark 2.3]: in every characteristic $\mathrm{PGL}_{2}(\mathbf{k})$ admits subgroups isomorphic to $A_{5}$ and to dihedral subgroups of all orders. For $A_{5}$, suppose the non-trivial stabilizers for the group action have size $s_{1}, \ldots, s_{k}$. Since this group scheme is reduced, we can apply Riemann-Hurwitz to the morphism $f^{\prime}: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ obtained by the quotient to see that

$$
-2=60 \cdot(-2)+\sum_{i=1}^{k}\left(s_{i}-1\right) \frac{60}{s_{i}}
$$

A quick numerical computation shows that we must have $\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}, s_{3}\right\}=\{2,3,5\}$ or $\{2,2,30\}$. The latter is ruled out by the explicit description in [Fab23, Proposition 4.21] in characteristic $\neq 5$ and by [Fab23, Proposition 4.22] in characteristic 5. Thus the cover defines a free Campana curve. For the dihedral group, for simplicity we may increase the size so that it has the form $2 m$ with $m$ a prime different from $p$. Repeating the Riemann-Hurwitz computation above, the stabilizers must have size $\{2,2, m\}$ or size $\{2 m, 2 m\}$. It suffices to show that in characteristic 2 we can ensure that there are not two points that are fixed by

the entire group. This follows from [Fab23, Remark 2.1]. The rest of the argument is the same as in characteristic 0 .

Remark 7.2. Consider the Campana orbifold $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ with multiplicities $(2,3,4)$ in characteristic 2. [Fab23, Theorem A, Remark 2.3] shows that $\operatorname{PGL}_{2}(\mathbf{k})$ does not admit any subgroup isomorphic to the octahedral group $S_{4}$. While we can still construct a free curve $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ using an icosahedral subgroup instead, we do not know whether there exists a free curve cover $f^{\prime}: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{P}^{1}$ with the "minimal" possible ramification behavior.

Remark 7.3. We can now compare Campana's definition of orbifold uniruledness and orbifold rational connectedness to our notions. Suppose that $\left(X, \Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$ is a smooth klt Campana orbifold and that $f: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow X$ is a morphism whose image is not contained in $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\Delta_{\epsilon}\right)$. In [Cam11b] Campana says that $f$ is an orbifold rational curve if we can give $\mathbb{P}^{1}$ an orbifold structure $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Gamma_{\epsilon}\right)$ such that:
(1) $K_{\mathbb{P}^{1}}+\Gamma_{\epsilon}$ is antiample, and
(2) for every point $p \in \mathbb{P}^{1}$ and every irreducible component $\Delta_{i}$ we have $t_{i, p} \geq \frac{m_{i, p}}{n_{i, p}}$ whenever $t_{i, p}$ is positive where $t_{i, p}$ is the local multiplicity of $\Delta_{i}$ along $p$ and $m_{i, p}, n_{i, p}$ are respectively the multiplicities of $\Delta_{i}$ in $\Delta_{\epsilon}$ and $p$ in $\Gamma_{\epsilon}$.
He then defines orbifold uniruledness and orbifold rational connectedness using the existence of families of orbifold rational curves through one or two general points respectively.

A priori Campana's notion of an orbifold rational curve is more general than our notion of a Campana curve. Correspondingly, Campana's notions of uniruledness and rational connectedness are a priori more general than ours. However, by precomposing a map $f$ : $\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Gamma_{\epsilon}\right) \rightarrow(X, \Delta)$ by a free Campana curve $g: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow\left(\mathbb{P}^{1}, \Gamma_{\epsilon}\right)$ as in Theorem 7.1 we see that composition $f \circ g: \mathbb{P}^{1} \rightarrow(X, \Delta)$ is a Campana curve. In particular, any family of orbifold rational curves through one (or two) general points yields a Campana curve through one (or two) general points, showing that the two notions are equivalent.

# 8. Rational Campana Curves in toric Varieties
### 8.1. Log curves in toric targets.

8.1.1. The targets. Let $N \cong \mathbb{Z}^{d}$ be a lattice and $M=N^{\vee}$ be its dual lattice. Write $N_{\mathbb{R}}=$ $N \otimes_{\mathbb{Z}} \mathbb{R}$ and $M_{\mathbb{R}}=M \otimes_{\mathbb{Z}} \mathbb{R}$. For a fan $\Sigma$ in $N$, define the log scheme $X_{\Sigma}$ whose underlying variety is the toric variety $\underline{X_{\Sigma}}$ associated to the fan $\Sigma$ and whose log structure $\mathcal{M}_{X_{\Sigma}}$ is associated to the toric boundary $\Delta_{\Sigma} \subset \underline{X_{\Sigma}}$. Note that we do not require $\underline{X_{\Sigma}}$ to be smooth in general. However, the log scheme $X_{\Sigma}$ is always log smooth by [Kat89, Prop. 3.4]. Let $\Sigma^{(1)} \subset \Sigma$ be the collection of rays. For a ray $\rho \in \Sigma^{(1)}$, denote by $u_{\rho}$ its lattice generator and let $\Delta_{\rho} \subset X_{\Sigma}$ be the corresponding torus invariant divisor. Thus, we have $\Delta_{\Sigma}=\sum_{\rho \in \Sigma^{(1)}} \Delta_{\rho}$.
8.1.2. Contact orders. Consider $X_{\Sigma}$ as the target of log maps. The set of possible contact orders at a marked point is in bijection with the lattice points in the support of the fan $|\Sigma|$. In particular, if $\Sigma$ is complete, then a contact order at a marked point can be identified by an element of $N$. Below we will explain this bijection when $\Sigma$ is a smooth fan; the general case is described by [ACMW17, §5.2] and [ACGS20, §2.3.8].

In case $\Sigma$ is a smooth fan a lattice point $c \in N$ specifies a contact order as defined in $\S 2$ as follows. Let $\sigma \in \Sigma$ be the minimal cone containing $c$, and let $\sigma^{(1)}$ be the set of rays of $\sigma$.

The smoothness of the cone $\sigma$ implies a unique presentation $\mathbf{c}=\sum_{\rho \in \sigma^{(1)}} c_{\rho} u_{\rho}$ for a positive integer $c_{\rho}$ by the minimality of $\sigma$. Thus $\mathbf{c}$ specifies the contact order $c_{\rho}$ with respect to $\Delta_{\rho}$ if $\rho \in \sigma^{(1)}$, and 0 otherwise.
Remark 8.1. To any log smooth variety $X$ (where the underlying variety $\underline{X}$ is not necessarily smooth) one can associate a cone complex $\Sigma_{X}$ called the tropicalization of $X$. Then contact orders at a marked point are given precisely by the integral points of $\Sigma_{X}$. In the toric case $X=X_{\Sigma}$ as above, one checks that $\Sigma_{X}=\Sigma$ as cone complexes. In particular, the set of lattice points in $\Sigma$ are precisely the set of integral points of $\Sigma_{X}$.

This canonical assignment of contact orders in the general situation is explained in [ACMW17, §5.2] and [ACGS20, §2.3.8].

Henceforth we will identify a contact order with a lattice point in the support of the fan $|\Sigma|$ without any further mention.
8.1.3. Campana curves on toric varieties. Consider a $\log \operatorname{map} f: C \rightarrow X_{\Sigma}$ with the collection of contact orders $\varsigma=\left\{\mathbf{c}_{k}\right\}$. By intersection theory, this collection $\varsigma$ satisfies

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{c}_{k} \in \varsigma} \mathbf{c}_{k}=0
$$

which is called the balancing condition. Denote by $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma \subset N$ the sub-lattice generated by $\varsigma$.
Theorem 8.2. Let $\underline{X}_{\Sigma}$ be a smooth projective toric variety of dimension d corresponding to the fan $\Sigma$ with a SNC divisor $\Delta_{\Sigma} \subset \underline{X}_{\Sigma}$. Let $\varsigma$ be a collection of positive contact orders satisfying the balancing condition. Then
(1) $X_{\Sigma}$ is separably $\varsigma$-uniruled.
(2) If the sub-lattice $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma \subset N$ is of rank d, then $X_{\Sigma}$ is also rationally $\varsigma$-connected.
(3) If $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$ is of rank d, and $N /(\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma)$ contains no char $\mathbf{k}$-torsion, then $X_{\Sigma}$ is separably rationally $\varsigma$-connected.

Proof. Let $X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ be another toric target of dimension $d$. We will argue that the above statements for $X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ and for $X_{\Sigma}$ are equivalent. In particular, it suffices to consider the case that $\Sigma$ is the fan of a projective space, which then will be verified in Proposition 8.5 below.

Indeed, let $\pi: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow W, e v: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X_{\Sigma}$ be a family of non-degenerate log maps over an irreducible $W$ with contact orders $\varsigma$ as in Definition 4.1. Note that $X_{\Sigma}$ and $X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ share the same open dense tori $\mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$ with the trivial log structure. For each geometric point $s \in W$, the non-degeneracy of the fiber $e v_{s}: U_{s} \rightarrow X_{\Sigma}$ implies that $U_{s} \backslash e v_{s}^{-1}\left(\mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}\right)$ consists precisely of markings. Hence $e v_{s}$ induces a non-degenerate $\log \operatorname{map} e v_{s}^{\prime}: U_{s} \rightarrow X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ of contact order $\varsigma$. Thus, there is an open dense $W^{\prime} \subset W$ parametrizing non-degenerate log maps $e v^{\prime}: \mathcal{U} \rightarrow X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$.

If $X_{\Sigma}$ is separably $\varsigma$-uniruled, there is a family $W$ of genus zero non-degenerate stable $\log$ maps such that $\operatorname{dim} W=\operatorname{dim} X-1$ and $e v$ is dominant and separable. Then the corresponding family on $X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ parametrized by $W^{\prime}$ has the same properties, showing that $X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ is $\varsigma$-uniruled. Similarly, the properties of being rationally $\varsigma$-connected or separably rationally $\varsigma$-connected can be passed from $X_{\Sigma}$ to $X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ using an appropriate choice of $W$ as in Definition 4.1. Thus the desired statements for $X_{\Sigma^{\prime}}$ follow from the analogous statements for $X_{\Sigma}$.

Remark 8.3. In Theorem 8.2 above, we restrict our attention to smooth toric varieties with SNC boundary because we have only defined " $\varsigma$-uniruled" and " $\varsigma$-rationally connected" in this setting. We observe that the argument does not require that the fans $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ are

smooth; suitably interpreted, the claims are true for any (not necessarily smooth) complete fan $\Sigma$. A key point is to interpret contact orders as lattice points of fans as in Remark 8.1.

Since Theorem 8.2 only imposes the the balancing condition on $\varsigma$, we can find suitable families of rational curves satisfying any multiplicity conditions. For example:

Corollary 8.4. Suppose $(X, \Delta)$ is a projective klt Campana orbifold whose corresponding $\log$ scheme is $\left(X_{\Sigma}, \Delta_{\Sigma}\right)$ as in Theorem 8.2. Then $(X, \Delta)$ is separably Campana rationally connected by good contact orders.

Proof. Set $p=\operatorname{char}(\mathbf{k})$. Let $m_{i}$ denote the multiplicity associated to the irreducible component $\Delta_{i}$ of $\Delta_{\Sigma}$. Since $(X, \Delta)$ is klt, the constant $m=\sup _{i}\left\{m_{i}\right\}$ is finite. Let $\alpha$ be a curve class such that $\Delta_{i} \cdot \alpha \geq 2 m+2$ for every irreducible component $\Delta_{i}$. Thus we can write $\Delta_{i} \cdot \alpha=t_{i, 1}+t_{i, 2}$ where (1) both $t_{i, 1}$ and $t_{i, 2}$ are at least $m$, and (2) neither $t_{i, 1}$ or $t_{i, 2}$ is divisible by $p$.

We define the contact order $\varsigma$ which has two markings for each torus invariant $\Delta_{i}$ and at these markings we assign either $t_{i, 1}$ or $t_{i, 2}$ to $\Delta_{i}$ and 0 to every other torus-invariant divisor. Since sum of the orders of $\varsigma$ along $\Delta_{i}$ agrees with $\Delta_{i} \cdot \alpha$ the contact order satisfies the balancing condition. It is clear that $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$ has full rank. We claim that $N / \mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$ has no $p$-torsion. Indeed, suppose we fix a full-dimensional cone and consider the sublattice of $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$ spanned by the vectors in $\varsigma$ proportional to these rays. This already has no $p$-torsion, thus the same will be true for quotient by the entire sublattice $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$.

By Theorem 8.2 we see that $(X, \Delta)$ is separably rationally $\varsigma$-connected. Since $\varsigma$ satisfies the Campana condition this finishes the proof.

Proof of Corollary 1.10. Weak approximation for a smooth projective toric variety over $k(B)$ is known by [CTG04, Theorem 4.3]. Thus our assertion follows from Theorem 8.2 combined with Theorem 6.4.

# 8.2. Theorem 8.2 for projective spaces. 

8.2.1. The set-up. For a positive integer $d$, consider the $\log$ scheme $X_{d}=X_{\Sigma}$ where the underlying $\underline{X_{d}}=\mathbb{P}^{d}$ is projective space. Let $\rho_{0}, \rho_{1}, \cdots, \rho_{d}$ be the ray generators of the rays in $\Sigma^{(1)}$. These satisfy $\sum_{i=0}^{d} \rho_{i}=0$. By an abuse of notation, we sometimes identify the generators $\rho_{i}$ with the rays that they span. The toric boundary is $\Delta_{X_{d}}=\sum_{j=0}^{d} H_{j}$ where $H_{i}$ is the hyperplane corresponding to $\rho_{i}$. The complement $X_{d} \backslash \Delta_{X_{d}}=\mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$ is a rank $d$ torus. We may choose homogeneous coordinate functions $\left[x_{0}: \cdots: x_{d}\right]$ of $X_{d}$ such that $H_{i}=\left(x_{i}=0\right)$.
8.2.2. Parametrizing log curves in $X_{d}$. We fix a rational curve $\underline{C}=\mathbb{P}^{1}$ with the homogeneous coordinate functions $[s: t]$ and set $b_{\infty}=[1: 0] \in \underline{C}$. The complement $\underline{C} \backslash\left\{b_{\infty}\right\}=\mathbb{A}_{s / t}^{1}=$ Spec $\mathbf{k}[s / t]$ is an affine line.

To parametrize rational log curves with the fixed underlying domain $\underline{C}$, we fix a positive integer $\beta$ to be the curve class, and a collection of non-zero lattice points $\varsigma_{d}=\left\{\mathbf{c}_{k} \in N\right\}_{k}$ where $\mathbf{c}_{k}$ specifies the contact order at the $k$-th marking $p_{k}$ as described in $\S 8.1 .2$. Note that as a lattice point in $N$, we have

$$
\mathbf{c}_{k}=\sum_{i=0}^{d} c_{k, i} \rho_{i}
$$

The balancing condition (8.1) is a consequence of the intersection-theoretic constraint

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|} c_{k, i}=H_{i} \cdot \beta
$$

for every $i$, which we now impose.
On $\underline{C}$ we fix a collection of markings

$$
P:=\left\{p_{k}=s_{k} / t_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|} \subset \mathbb{A}_{s / t}^{1}
$$

Suppose $f: C \rightarrow X_{d}$ is a non-degenerate rational log map with assigned contact orders $\varsigma_{d}$ at the markings $P$. On the level of homogeneous coordinates, for each $i$ we have

$$
f^{*} x_{i}=\lambda_{i} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}\left(t \cdot s_{k}-s \cdot t_{k}\right)^{c_{k, i}}
$$

for some $\lambda_{i} \in \mathbf{k}^{\times}$since $f$ is non-degenerate. Inserting $b_{\infty}=[1: 0]$ to (8.3), we have

$$
f^{*} x_{i}\left(b_{\infty}\right)=\lambda_{i} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}\left(-t_{k}\right)^{c_{k, i}}
$$

Since $t_{k} \neq 0$, we observe that $\left(\lambda_{i}\right)_{i}$ hence $f$ is uniquely determined by the image $f\left(b_{\infty}\right) \in \mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$. Conversely, any such prescription determines a morphism $f: C \rightarrow X_{d}$ with the desired contact orders.

Denote by

$$
U_{\varsigma} \subset\left(\mathbb{A}_{s / t}^{1}\right)^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|} \times \mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}
$$

the open subscheme parametrizing $\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|$ distinct points in $\mathbb{A}_{s / t}^{1}$ (representing the set of markings (8.2)) and a point $x_{\infty} \in \mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$ (representing the image of $b_{\infty}$ ). Let $\pi: \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma} \rightarrow U_{\varsigma}$ be the family of log curves with markings specified by $U_{\varsigma}$. Note that $\underline{\mathcal{C}_{\varsigma}} \cong \underline{C} \times U_{\varsigma}$. We obtain a family of non-degenerate log curves

$$
f_{\varsigma}: \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma} \rightarrow X_{d}
$$

over $U_{\varsigma}$, fiberwise determined by (8.3), such that $f_{\varsigma}\left(b_{\infty}\right)=x_{\infty}$.
Proposition 8.5. Theorem 8.2 holds for $X_{d}$.
Proof. The balancing condition and the parametrization (8.3) imply the existence of rational $\log$ curves in $X_{d}$ with contact order $\varsigma$. Theorem 8.2 (1) for $X_{d}$ follows by using the $\mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$-action.

Now consider the 2-evaluation map

$$
e v^{(2)}:=f_{\varsigma} \times_{U_{\varsigma}} f_{\varsigma}: \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma} \times_{U_{\varsigma}} \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma} \rightarrow X_{d} \times X_{d}
$$

Assume that $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$ is of rank $d$. To prove Theorem 8.2 (2) for $X_{d}$, we will show that $e v^{(2)}$ is dominant. It suffices to show that there is an $f$ defined as in (8.3) passing through a general pair of points $x, y \in \mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$. Let $b_{0}=[0: 1] \in \underline{C}$. We will construct such $f$ satisfying

$$
f\left(b_{\infty}\right)=x, \quad f\left(b_{0}\right)=y, \quad b_{0} \notin P
$$

Let $V^{\circ} \subset\left(\mathbb{A}_{s / t}^{1} \backslash\left\{b_{0}\right\}\right)^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}$ be the open subscheme parametrizing $\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|$ distinct points in $\mathbb{A}_{s / t}^{1} \backslash$ $\left\{b_{0}\right\}$ as the set of markings (8.2). Consider the locally closed subscheme $V_{\varsigma}:=V^{\circ} \times\{x\} \subset U_{\varsigma}$. By (8.3), the restriction $\left.\left(f_{\varsigma}\right)\right|_{\left\{b_{0}\right\} \times V_{\varsigma}}:\left\{b_{0}\right\} \times V_{\varsigma} \rightarrow X_{d}$ factors through $\mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$, and is defined by

$$
\left.\left(f_{\varsigma}\right|_{\left\{b_{0}\right\} \times V_{\varsigma}}\right)^{*} x_{i}=\lambda_{i} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|} s_{k}^{c_{k, i}}
$$

As $b_{0}, b_{\infty} \notin P$, we may assume that $t_{k}=-1$ for all $k$ and $s_{k} \neq s_{k^{\prime}}$ for $k \neq k^{\prime}$. Hence for any $i, \lambda_{i}$ is the $i$-th homogeneous coordinate of $x$. Interpreting $\left(\mathbb{A}_{s / t}^{1} \backslash\left\{b_{0}\right\}\right)^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}$ as a torus, we see that the dimension of the image of $\left.\left(f_{\varsigma}\right)\right|_{\left\{b_{0}\right\} \times V_{\varsigma}}$ is given by the rank of $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$, which is $d$. In particular, $\left.\left(f_{\varsigma}\right)\right|_{\left\{b_{0}\right\} \times V_{\varsigma}}$ is dominant, implying that we can send $b_{0}$ to a designated general point $y$.

To prove Theorem 8.2 (3) for $X_{d}$, it suffices to show that

$$
\mathrm{d} e v^{(2)}: T_{\mathcal{C}_{\varsigma} \times U_{\varsigma} \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma}} \rightarrow\left(e v^{(2)}\right)^{*} T_{X_{d} \times X_{d}}
$$

is surjective at the point $\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right) \in \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma} \times_{U_{\varsigma}} \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma}$ for some general point $u \in U_{\varsigma}$. To compute $\mathrm{d} e v^{(2)}$, we choose the coordinate functions

$$
\tilde{t}, \tilde{s}, \tilde{\lambda}_{1}, \cdots, \tilde{\lambda}_{d}, \tilde{s}_{1}, \cdots, \tilde{s}_{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}
$$

around $\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right) \in \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma} \times_{U_{\varsigma}} \mathcal{C}_{\varsigma}$, and the coordinate functions

$$
\tilde{x}_{1}, \cdots, \tilde{x}_{d}, \tilde{y}_{1}, \cdots, \tilde{y}_{d}
$$

around the image $e v^{(2)}\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right) \in X_{d} \times X_{d}$ as follows.
Let $\tilde{t}=t / s$ (resp. $\tilde{s}=s / t$ ) be the coordinate around $b_{\infty} \in C_{d}$ (resp. $b_{0} \in C_{d}$ ). Choose a general $u$ so that for any $p_{k} \in P$, we may assume $t_{k}=-1$, hence $\tilde{s}_{k}=s_{k} / t_{k}$ is the coordinate around $p_{k} \in \mathcal{C}_{d}$. In particular, we have $p_{k} \neq b_{0}$ for any $p_{k} \in P$, hence the image $e v^{(2)}\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)$ avoids the boundary of $X_{d}$. Let $x_{0}, \cdots, x_{d}$ and $y_{0}, \cdots, y_{d}$ be the homogeneous coordinates of $X_{d} \times X_{d}$. We may assume that the coordinates around $e v^{(2)}\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right) \in X_{d} \times X_{d}$ are given by $\tilde{x}_{1}=x_{1} / x_{0}, \cdots, \tilde{x}_{d}=x_{d} / x_{0}$ and $\tilde{y}_{1}=y_{1} / y_{0}, \cdots, \tilde{y}_{d}=y_{d} / y_{0}$ and $x_{0}=y_{0}=1$ at the point $e v^{(2)}\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)$. Consequently by (8.4), the coordinate around $f_{\varsigma}\left(b_{\infty}\right) \in \mathbb{G}_{m}^{d}$ is given by $\tilde{\lambda}_{1}=\lambda_{1} / \lambda_{0}, \cdots, \tilde{\lambda}_{d}=\lambda_{d} / \lambda_{0}$ with $\lambda_{0}=1$ at $f_{\varsigma}\left(b_{\infty}\right)$.

Under the above choices of coordinates, using (8.3) we have
$\left(e v^{(2)}\right)^{*} \tilde{x}_{i}=\tilde{\lambda}_{i} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}\left(\tilde{s}_{k}+\tilde{s}\right)^{c_{k, i}} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}\left(\tilde{s}_{k}+\tilde{s}\right)^{-c_{k, 0}}, \quad\left(e v^{(2)}\right)^{*} \tilde{y}_{i}=\tilde{\lambda}_{i} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}\left(\tilde{t} \cdot \tilde{s}_{k}+1\right)^{c_{k, i}} \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|}\left(\tilde{t} \cdot \tilde{s}_{k}+1\right)^{-c_{k, 0}}$
around $\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)$ for $i=1, \cdots, d$. Now the fiber $\left.\mathrm{d} e v^{(2)}\right|_{\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)}$ is given by evaluating the following $(2 d) \times\left(d+\left|\varsigma_{d}\right|+2\right)$ Jacobian matrix

$$
\left[\begin{array}{lll}
\left(\frac{\partial \tilde{x}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{\lambda}_{j}}\right)_{i, j} & \left(\frac{\partial \tilde{x}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{s}_{k}}\right)_{i, k} & \left(\frac{\partial \tilde{x}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{s}}\right)_{i} & \left(\frac{\partial \tilde{x}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{\lambda}}\right)_{i} \\
\left(\frac{\partial \tilde{y}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{\lambda}_{j}}\right)_{i, j} & \left(\frac{\partial \tilde{y}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{s}_{k}}\right)_{i, k} & \left(\frac{\partial \tilde{y}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{s}}\right)_{i} & \left(\frac{\partial \tilde{y}_{s}}{\partial \tilde{\lambda}}\right)_{i}
\end{array}\right]
$$

at $\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)$. Note that $\left|\varsigma_{d}\right| \geq(d+1)$ as $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma$ is of rank $d$, and $\varsigma_{d}$ satisfies the balancing condition. It suffices to verify the above matrix is of rank $2 d$.

A direct calculation shows that

$$
\left.\left(\frac{\partial \tilde{y}_{i}}{\partial \tilde{\lambda}_{j}}\right)_{i, j}\right|_{\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)}=I_{d \times d}
$$

where $I_{d \times d}$ is the $d \times d$ identity matrix. Next, we compute that

$$
\left.\frac{\partial \tilde{x}_{i}}{\partial \tilde{s}_{k}}\right|_{\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)}=\left(c_{k, i}-c_{k, 0}\right) \frac{\lambda_{i}}{\tilde{s}_{k}} \cdot \prod_{\ell=1}^{\left|\zeta_{d}\right|} \tilde{s}_{\ell}^{c_{\ell, i}-c_{\ell, 0}}
$$

As the factor $\frac{\lambda_{i}}{\tilde{s}_{k}} \cdot \prod_{\ell=1}^{\left|\zeta_{d}\right|} \tilde{s}_{\ell}^{c_{\ell, i}-c_{\ell, 0}} \neq 0$, the rank of the matrix $\left(\left.\frac{\partial \tilde{x}_{i}}{\partial \tilde{s}_{k}}\right)_{i, k}\right|_{\left(b_{0}, u, b_{\infty}\right)}$ is the same as the rank of the $d \times\left|\zeta_{d}\right|$-matrix

$$
\left(c_{k, i}-c_{k, 0}\right)_{i, k} \quad \bmod \operatorname{char} \mathbf{k}
$$

where $i$ runs through $\{1,2, \cdots, d\}$ and $k$ runs through $\{1,2, \cdots,\left|\zeta_{d}\right|\}$.
To compute the rank of (8.8), let $\tilde{N} \cong \mathbb{Z}^{d+1}$ be the lattice with generators $\left\{\tilde{\rho}_{0}, \cdots, \tilde{\rho}_{d}\right\}$. Consider the surjective morphism of lattices

$$
\varphi: \tilde{N} \longrightarrow N, \quad \tilde{\rho}_{i} \mapsto \rho_{i}
$$

where $\rho_{i}$ is the lattice generator of the $i$-th ray of the fan $\Sigma^{(1)}$. Denote by $\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{k}=\sum_{i} c_{k, i} \tilde{\rho}_{i} \in \tilde{N}$. Then observe that $\varphi\left(\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{k}\right)=\mathbf{c}_{k}$ where we view $\mathbf{c}_{k} \in N$ as the lattice point. Let $\mathbb{Z} \cdot \tilde{\varsigma} \subset \tilde{N}$ be the sub-lattice generated by $\tilde{\varsigma}=\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{c}}_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{|\zeta|}$.

Let $M$ and $\tilde{M}$ be the dual lattices of $N$ and $\tilde{N}$ respectively. Taking the dual of $\varphi$, we obtain an injection of lattices $\varphi^{\vee}: M \hookrightarrow \tilde{M}$. Let $\left\{\tilde{\rho}_{i}^{\vee}\right\}_{i=0}^{d}$ be the basis of $\tilde{M}$ dual to $\left\{\tilde{\rho}_{i}\right\}_{i=0}^{d}$. Then as a sub-lattice via $\varphi^{\vee}, M$ has a basis $\left\{\rho_{i}^{\vee}:=\tilde{\rho}_{i}^{\vee}-\tilde{\rho}_{0}^{\vee}\right\}_{i=1}^{d}$ dual to the basis $\left\{\rho_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{d}$ of $N$. Observe that

$$
c_{k, i}-c_{k, 0}=\left(\tilde{\rho}_{i}^{\vee}-\tilde{\rho}_{0}^{\vee}\right)\left(\mathbf{c}_{k}\right)
$$

Thus, the rank of (8.8) is the dimension of

$$
\left.M\right|_{\mathbb{Z} \cdot \tilde{\varsigma}}=\left.M\right|_{\mathbb{Z} \cdot \tilde{\varsigma}} \bmod \operatorname{char} \mathbf{k}
$$

Here we view $\left.M\right|_{*}$ as the space of linear functions defined on $*$. Finally, as $N /(\mathbb{Z} \cdot \varsigma)$ has no char k-torsion, we observe that $\left.M\right|_{\mathbb{Z} \cdot \tilde{\varsigma}}$ is of dimension $d$ as needed.

This finishes the proof.
Proof of Theorem 1.8. This follows from Theorem 8.2 and Corollary 8.4.

abstract:
Campana introduced a notion of Campana rational connectedness for Campana
orbifolds. Given a Campana fibration over a complex curve, we prove that a
version of weak approximation for Campana sections holds at places of good
reduction when the general fiber satisfies a slightly stronger version of
Campana rational connectedness. Campana also conjectured that any Fano orbifold
is Campana rationally connected; we verify a stronger statement for toric
Campana orbifolds. A key tool in our study is log geometry and moduli stacks of
stable log maps.
